148542739.review:
[b] [i] > Be me
> Looking for a game that screams "wacky"
> Stumble upon Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit
> "This sounds like my kind of chaos!"

> Start the game
> Meet Ash, the rabbit prince of hell
> He's got a freaking jetpack-drill thing
> "Okay, this is already insane"

> Explore the bizarre hellish world
> Fight demonic monsters in cute outfits
> Wonder what the designers were smoking

> Discover the "Island of Barrels"
> Spend hours destroying every darn barrel
> Can't resist the satisfying kaboom

> Meet the 100 Overlords of Hell
> They're quirky, they're odd, they're downright hilarious
> "I wish my boss was a giant rubber ducky too"

> Customizing the drill with crazy upgrades
> Now it shoots explosive penguins
> Laugh maniacally at the chaos

> Uncover Ash's embarrassing secret photos
> He's wearing a tutu, playing the ukulele
> Can't stop laughing at this edgy rabbit

> Engage in over-the-top boss battles
> Defeat a giant psycho bear with a chainsaw
> "Only in a game like this, man"

> Enjoy the humorous pop culture references
> Spot nods to classic movies and games
> "Who knew hell could be this fun?"

> Finish the game with a smile
> Reflect on the absurdity of it all
> "Hell Yeah! was one hell of a wild ride!"  [/i]🐰🔥💣🎮😈🌟 [/B]

[i] "Well, strap on your drill-jetpack thingamajig and prepare for a trip down to the devil's workshop, because 'Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit' is the kind of fever dream that only a team of caffeinated game designers could conjure up.

First, the visuals; this game looks like an acid trip through a demented cartoonist's sketchbook. The vibrant, chaotic hellscapes and the downright ludicrous character designs are a delight to behold, assuming you've got the stomach for an onslaught of over-the-top visual insanity.

The gameplay, while not revolutionary, is a heady mix of platforming, shooting, and exploration, all tied together with a satisfyingly bonkers drill mechanic. There's a gleeful sense of empowerment that comes from turning demonic baddies into gory confetti with your trusty, customizable drill.

But where 'Hell Yeah!' truly shines is its unapologetic commitment to sheer lunacy. From the outrageously bizarre boss fights to the shamelessly juvenile humor, this game revels in its own absurdity. It's a madcap carnival ride through hell, complete with explosive penguins and a chainsaw-wielding psycho bear.

Sure, it's not going to win any awards for its depth of storytelling or groundbreaking mechanics, but for a raucous, devilishly good time, 'Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit' is an unapologetically gleeful romp through a realm where the only rule is 'the more ludicrous, the better.' Just make sure you're wearing your insanity goggles." [/i]

138306065.review:
I had a really fun 8 or so hours with the game. The game is split into two types of gameplay for the most part. A sort of weapon focused jetpack gameplay and on-foot pure platforming when the game forces you out of your jetpack-wheel thingy. Both are good.  I could've done without some of the vehicle sections though.

The game has some flaws. One is the inconsistent minigames you have to do just about every time you kill one of the game's 100+ monsters. Along with that some of the more difficult "missions", optional side challenges you complete for unlockables are basically RNG based since the challenge never completely resets when you fail it resulting in platforms that are out of place in challenges which have damn near 0 margin for error.

Regardless, I had a fantastic time with Hell Yeah!  It's sad that the dev studio closed it's doors in 2013, but if they ever return, I wouldn't mind a sequel to this. I can tell that they had just as much fun making this as I had playing it.

135032956.review:
A rabbit with a gun? Hell Yeah!

The kid in you says Hell Yeah, and you gotta agree to it…

It’s sort of like Jazz Jackrabbit, but a bit more ridiculous and with a lot more blood and explosions.

I’ve never laughed so much playing a game. It was though in parts and the mechanics weren’t perfect but this game is brilliant.

Feels a lot like a late 90s era Sega platformer: cartoony graphics but weird setting, sort of open exploration levels with a lot of verticality, etc.

The art is cool, the writing is about what you would expect, and the death animations fill me with so much joy, it’s probably unhealthy. Also, the music is awesome.

It does look a bit gimmicky, but I felt the humor makes up for it. Oh, and there’s upgradeable and unlockable weapons.

The over the top edginess is kind of the point of the game. I mean the name of the game is HELL YEAH!!! (Guitar scream in the background). I actually still listen to the fuzzy bunny song all the time because it’s so damn funny.

It’s not perfect, the controls can be a bit wonky, but it’s all around fun - edgy as all hell (again, the point. You’re playing the master of hell who wants to get his nude pictures back... I mean come on), good monsters, the levels vary just enough to be cool but not enough for you to just be confused… etc. It’s like a slower but more violent Sonic.

Finally, only courageous half dead rabbits with the brain of burnt seed will be able to appreciate this gem.

10/10

128460745.review: While this was one of my childhood games, I still have a lot of fun playing it. Even though I haven't quite beaten the game yet, I'm pretty far and I'm pretty sure there's some end-game content. The puzzles in this game aren't too difficult but not easy to the point that anyone could solve them without effort. The combat is simple but the bosses are especially enjoyable (still a lot easier than games like hollow knight or blasphemous). Each area of the game has different features to go through and the minigames for each monster can be kinda fun sometimes. While it seems like you can get easily lost, the game has a lot of features like a minimap/map and arrows which will show you where you need to go. In a way this game is a comedy with heavy cartoon-ish gore. I recommend that you give it a try, the price is reasonable for the amount of content.

111623693.review:
5.3.2022.

Game #193

[h1] Only Sega can make a game like this… [/h1]

When I was young, I used to have a Sega Mega Drive (Genesis) console. I love my old sega games but ever since Sega got out of the console business… they just can’t make a good game if their life depended on it. Every time Sega releases a game it’s mediocre at best and unplayable at worst. 
Even, Yakuza https://store.steampowered.com/app/638970/Yakuza_0/ , a series I love, is plagued with sega trademark gameplay design choices that almost ruin the whole experience.

So, when you see a game about an undead rabbit, riding a chain blade with guns killing creatures of hell, you just know that if anyone could mess up such a concept, it can only be Sega.

[h1] That name though… [/h1]

I think I’m wise enough to know that if someone’s trying way too hard to sound cool, they probably aren’t very cool at all. This game wants to make you think it’s cool from the very title screen. “HELL YEAH!”, it’s only because of this name that I’ve put off playing this game for so long (the negative reviews helped too). 
Sega was trying really hard to make this game sound cool, and just like most of their game, it faded into obscurity just like all other niche games they make.

[h1] Demonic prices don’t bathe with rubber ducks [/h1]

Our story takes place in hell. The prince of hell, a skeletal Rabbit named Ash, is a vicious but respected ruler. However, one day he gets caught by a paparazzi having a bath with a rubber duck. This picture is released on the web and exactly 100 residents of hell see the picture and start calling him a “p****”.
Needless to say, Prince Ash doesn’t take kindly to such a post, so he sets out to do the only logical thing: kill every one of those 100 demons and erase any trace of anyone ever knowing that he likes playing with rubber ducks. I gotta admit, I do like such silly storytelling.
You’ll move from area to area, killing demons until you kill enough to move to the next one. You can’t really miss out on any of them either but thankfully you have a radar that helps you locate them.

[h1] Started off really well but slowly started to degrade[/h1]

When I first started playing the game… I actually had a lot of fun. The game starts off as a decent 2D action platformer but as you progress,  you get power ups, new moves and a world map, so it kinda shifts into a metroidvania but, well, you don’t really need to go back and collect things, so it hardly feels like one.

Anyway, you will start the game with just the ability to jump but pretty soon, you’ll get your first weapon: the chainblade. Simply hold the mouse button/controller trigger and mow everything down in your sight. It’s a lot of fun… or at least it was.
Soon after, you’ll come across a shotgun and a machinegun and the game will start playing like a twin stick shooter. The chain blade will only be used to go through walls from then on… see what I mean about Sega ruining good things?

[h1] Loose controls and enemies draining your health fast [/h1]

Even though you won’t notice it at first, the controls in the game are really loose. Jumping works well but everything else just kinda feels all over the place. When you learn wall jump, the game tells you to hold the jump button when you attempt to do it, however, it seems to not work when you need it the most. Apparently some walls can be wall jumped and some can’t.

You do have a health bar in the game, but it may as well not even be there. They should have just replaced it with 3 hits, or something, because that’s how long it usually takes to die. Also remember that chain blade? Yeah, it pretty much stops working on enemies once you get guns and if an enemy touches you it’ll just drain your health. 

While dying isn’t a huge deal thanks to a good checkpoint system, it’s still frustrating to do boss and mini-boss fights over and over again, especially when it comes to the next mechanic.

[h1] Micro games [/h1]

This next part was a roller-coaster ride for me. While you have trash mobs around the game, the main goal is killing the 100 individuals that saw the incriminating picture. Each one of these 100 enemies acts like a mini boss or a large boss of sorts. You have to damage them enough until their health drops to 0, however, when this happens, you also have to play a micro-game for the finish.
If you’ve ever played Ware-were, you’ll know what these are like. These are games that you literally have seconds to complete.
At first I thought this was pretty cool. You have to mash a button or wait for the right time to press the button in order to do an execution. Kind of like a “Finish Him” in Mortal Kombat https://store.steampowered.com/app/976310/Mortal_Kombat11/ . 

HOWEVER, unlike finishers in Mortal Kombat, you don’t really have a choice here. You have to do these finishers in order to kill the enemies. If you fail them, and you will, you’ll lose health, the mini boss will gain some back and you’ll have to damage them again and pass the micro-game again to truly kill them.

[h1] Search and destroy [/h1]
This was basically my “Quit moment” in this game. During a mini-boss fight, I drained the guy’s health to 0 and then got the infamous “search and destroy” micro game. In this micro game, you have to move your mouse/control stick to control a crosshair. You have your entire screen to locate an odd smiley and shoot it. Unfortunately, you only have 3 seconds to find the odd one out. 
After failing 15 times at this mini-game, I went online and noticed that other people had trouble with this. 

So, let me just sum this up: I’m unable to kill a mini-boss because it requires a finisher that’s gated by a badly designed micro-game. 

And that, my friends, is why this game sucks

[h1] Should have been fun but it ended up just being frustrating [/h1]

The thing that really frustrates me about “Hell Yeah!”is how this could have been such a nice game if the developers just stopped and said “Maybe we shouldn’t put so much stuff in our game!”. Honestly, I can’t recommend this game to anyone. While it’s sound good and looks good, it’s anything but good when you actually start playing it.

Next game: Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice

100069448.review:
Given the fact that 8.8% of players have gotten the achievement for beating the game should show that it's honestly not really worth your time. It seems good at first but there's really not much there and don't even get me started on the QTE nonsense. They aren't fun, you can tell it's a "big joke" like calling out Quick Time Events being overused in gaming, but they are being worse than the problem. They are always disorienting, sometimes downright confusing to even understand requiring multiple tries to even figure out (looking at you "find the out of place egg"). That wouldn't even be a problem if the game didn't penalize you so hard for messing one up, so in most cases you are being sent back to the last checkpoint to have to run all the way back and try again. It gets really old, really fast. The levels are boring, the weapons are boring, everything is just really boring and not all that fun.

I've had this game for a long time, bought it in 2012 and played a bit and stopped. Revisited it in 2016 and got bored and stopped then too. I went back this year to at least complete it for the achievements. Which is pretty insane because I had become fed up with the game very close to the end (85 monsters out of 101). There is a bit more to do past what I have done and I am at least thankful they didn't force that upon anyone with achievements. That said, I will not be going back and doing the extra missions. I will not be getting the DLC. I don't even think this game is worth it on sale, don't waste your time here.

TL:DR:
Game is bland, runs too many jokes into the ground, and just plain sucks. Avoid at all costs.

89510834.review:
Good reminder that not every game sitting in your library is actually worth playing.

I don't think "Hell yeah" could every be considered good, but somewhere in 8 years since the initial release it left the limbo of mediocrity and firmly planted itself on one of the deeper circles of video game hell.
Nearly every aspect of the game is dated as they hail from the age of XBox Live Arcade and Playgrounds. I struggle to think of any part of the game I liked. To make my point, let's just go through the list.

Graphics/Artstyle: Lurid colors and screen shaking, vomit inducing animations. Character and monster designs that came straight from the margins of a textbook, doodled by a bored elementary school kid. The game revels in mindless gratuitous over the top cartoonish violence, complete with buckets of blood, entrails and viscera. 

Narrative/Writing: The game attempts to be edgy, reckless and "cool with the kids". Or at least what writers imagined kids to be like back in 2012.  Writing abandons such unnecessary concepts as plot, character development and generally making sense, and gleefully buries the player under the avalanche of bad puns, fourth wall breaks, unnecessary dialogue snippets, ran-dumb jokes and pitiful one-liners. And for all the murderfest, all the violence, all the huffing and puffing with the insults that characters sling at each other, the Prince of Hell is too scared to drop an f-bomb. Can't have that in my good Christian game.

Gameplay: Floaty controls. Forgettable enemies. Abundance of infantile QTEs/Fatalities as a crutch for unsatisfying gameplay. Dedicated button to zoom out because otherwise you will keep falling into spikes. On that note, a lot of spikes that kill with a touch and send you back to the last checkpoint. Infrequent checkpoints that for some inexplicably reason can respawn you with a sliver of HP. Pointless unlocks as most weapons work similarly to each other. 

Audio: Other than the credits song every track sounds like something you're find by searching "free generic [genre] music download".

"Hell Yeah" may be fun for some people, who are into the over the top, abandon cartoon violence, but even then isn't worth full price. Otherwise, just play it if you received it for free like myself and have a sort of archaeological interest in the age in which this digital fossil was made.

87416623.review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 10.6h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No (2 achievements might be grindy to some people).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (11 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Has the stress got to you recently? Do you feel like venting it up somewhere else? [b]Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit[/b] can help you with that. It's a side-scroller platformer game where you can fight mini-bosses and unleash amazing finishing moves to finish them off. It's just what you're looking for, right? Hell yeah!

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Satisfying finishing moves on mini-bosses
- Useful minimap
- Unique boss fights
- Varying gameplay in some areas

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Some bosses are tricky to beat
- Useless island features
- Unable to skip cutscenes

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you are looking for a stress-reliever game, buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
[b]Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit[/b] is filled with 2D, cartoonish characters with the addition of foggy and lighting effects. The use of both effects makes the characters look softer and blend well with the background, especially with the background that is portrayed in a more realistic style compared to the characters. Some objects still retain the same 2D look although the terrain and walls are looking more like 3D in 2D plane with the lack of black outline and the use of shadows.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story isn't the main point of this game. Some dialogues act as fillers or tutorials and can be safely ignored if you choose to do so. The only important story is the cutscene at the beginning and end of the game, which also doesn't mean much in the first place. Despite the meaningless story, the game doesn't offer a skip function for the dialogues. This tends to give some trouble when you are repeating some boss fights since you have to read the same dialogues over and over again.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Exploring the area and killing mini-bosses are the core of this game. The game starts just like other platformer games where you have to explore the whole area to reach the boss room. Some parts of the area are locked and can only be accessible by defeating some mini-bosses, which are spread across the entire zone. Luckily, you don't have to worry about finding them - the game has a very useful minimap to help you find whatever you want, whether it's a healing point, the next boss location, or other important features that will be unlocked later in the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2407345193 

Although most zones have the same mechanic, some will require you to play by a certain rule. One zone requires you to clear some area without using your weapon, forcing you to either use a turret or utilize the environmental hazards to kill the mini-bosses. Some zones will also change the game into more of a shooter genre, where you control either a rocket or submarine and explore the area to defeat the remaining mini-bosses. These varying mechanics add more variety to the game and makes it not too repetitive.

[b]Combat[/b]
The game is packed full of combat scenes, and it doesn't disappoint. Over 100 mini-bosses are spread across 10 zones for you to beat, all with different attack patterns and methods to beat. Although most enemies can be defeated with your guns, some bosses are trickier to beat, requiring you to either use the environmental hazard or the new mechanic that is exclusive to that zone. However, although the game will give you some hints on how to kill these unique mini-bosses, some hints are not clear enough, causing confusion as to what to do.

Killing mini-bosses is fun and rewarding. Depleting the mini-bosses' health will trigger a minigame which you must complete to kill the mini-boss. There is no correlation between the minigame and the mini-bosses - you need to do some ridiculous actions such as answering a silly multiple-choice question, squeezing the enemy by smashing the Space button, or the others before the killing scene kicks in. The game will show the killing scene in [b]Danganronpa[/b] style afterward, connecting the ridiculous minigame with the killing in a hyperbolic way. Although the game has different minigames at first, the same minigame will be reused later on, reducing the satisfaction of killing them.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2407344789 

Three unique bosses will be spread across some zones for you to beat. These bosses are tougher than the mini-bosses and can be a bit bothersome at first, especially if you are not good at platformer games. Learning the attack patterns is vital in defeating these bosses, and if you are good at the game, you also can try to defeat them without losing any health. To be honest, defeating these bosses doesn't feel satisfying compared to the mini-bosses since there aren't any cool killing scenes at the end of the fight.

[b]Missions[/b]
Three missions are available to take in each zone and finishing them will net you some rewards. The missions are usually divided into four types: killing enemies, reaching the goal, collecting coins, and performing tricks. While the first three are simple enough to beat as long as you keep on trying, the last one is not keyboard-friendly. You need to reach a high altitude and turn your analog stick to perform tricks. Due to the control scheme, it makes the "turning the analog stick clockwise" to be "pressing the WASD button in succession" on the keyboard, making the command to be harder to execute. Moreover, the instruction tends to not be clear in this regard that I couldn't complete one mission because of this.

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in 9h and continued playing the DLC content for 1.5h. The rest of my playtime is spent in farming the death achievement, which doesn't take long since I already died a lot from playing the DLC content. The game was easy to beat, to the point that you just need to charge your way in most of the time to defeat the mini-bosses. There were some areas, especially the boss fights, that require some skills to beat, but that shouldn't give you too much trouble, especially since the game provides a lot of weapon upgrades and buffs.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2407347762 

[b]Problems[/b]
The game has an island feature where you can take your defeated mini-bosses and force them to work for you, giving you some in-game bonuses in return. However, I hardly got any bonuses before I finished the game and it turns out that the bonuses aren't much use either. Moreover, it took some time and effort to assign the mini-bosses to work that it doesn't feel rewarding to do.

[h3]Specs[/h3]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
To be honest, I didn't expect much from this game, especially since it was an old game that I never heard about. However, the game turned out to be a great stress-reliever, and it works wonders with the easy-to-play and satisfying gameplay. It might have been designed to be played in short bursts, but I have finished zones after zones without realizing it. It's all thanks to the finishing moves that show up after defeating the mini-bosses, and I couldn't stress enough how satisfying it is to watch.

79650396.review:
[h1]DECAP ATTACK's SPIRITUAL SUCCESSOR[/h1]

The time circa 2010 was seemingly a time people within Sega did a push for a return to form. A step away from Sega's obsession with 3D Sonic and a return to the fantasy and whimsy that characterized a Sega that wanted to have FUN. It was when we saw Bayonetta, PSO 2 (which I reviewed as well), the beautiful Castle of Illusion remake, and yes, this game. If you got my reference in the title, then that's all you need to know about this game, and should be playing it already.

Ash, the rabbit prince of hell, is on a rampage seeking the stalker that distributed pictures of him bathing with a rubber ducky, thus tarnishing his image as ultimate evil. The game is a spooky platformer full of different weapons, upgrades, banter with mini bosses, and gory, humorous executions that Sega wouldn't have been able to get away with back in the nineties. While the game is by no means a metroidvania, there is some backtracking in the game since each state has parts your chopping wheel can't access.

Another charming part of the game is that defeated enemies are sent to a slave island where they toil for money and powerups you can use in the game, and is sort of a clicker game.

The music isn't bad but it's nothing to write home about (also it tends to glitch out), and the art style accomplishes its purpose.

It's a simple game, so there's not not much more to talk about. A simple game, and reminiscent of simpler times, good times. If you're a fan of old Sega or 2D platformers, you'll do well in getting this game.

75877638.review:
I had a heck of alot of fun here so its an easy recommendation to the right player, but its far from flawless.

This games charm lies soley with its gory style and silly humor.It's layered into the gameplay, the story and everything else and if it's not enough to get a smile out of you the flaws will overshadow your experience.

This game is a best described as a cross between a metroidvania and Warioware. Your objective is to hunt down and kill 100 specific monster defended by theirs own unique mechanics and microgame. It's a combination of platforming and puzzle solving as you find each monsters weakness and splatter its innards all over your screen.

But with so many mecahnics it does fall into the "Master of none" feeling fairly The controls are floaty and imprecise, the balance is 100% out whack and the end game starts repeating mechanics and coming very close to outstaying its welcome. It leads to an uneven experience of I'm having fun to crashing into a wall repeatedly as you try to decipher the designer's joke to make progress. Visually the polish is all here, but mechanically it's just not.

It ends up a weird balance of a highly casual game with a low difficulty level that spawns into a highly casual game with enemies that one shot kill you despite owning all the health power ups. It's not a hard game, but it seems to randomly forget that. Casual laughs turn to random "SCREW YOU GAMES!" and then go back to laughs.

But even with my frustrations, I genuinely enjoyed the experience. When my bunny spawned into the world of his own personal hell I smiled ear to ear and danced my way to the next stage. The majority of the puzzles were just the right level of confusion to logical and it wasn't until the last 3rd of the game that the flaws took center stage.

I liked the humor, I loved the visuals and the microgames. For me, they outweighed the flaws to the point that I'd buy a sequel. But I'm also glad it ended when it did because it neared its breaking point.

72483758.review:
As part of my mission to actually play some of the games I've amassed in my library over the years, I knocked out Hell Yeah! over the course of of a few days. I think I got this game as part of a bundle, or it might've been a free giveaway from Sega for something or other, can't remember. 

Hell Yeah! is pretty unique overall. It's a mish-mosh of many things, but I think the safest way to describe it is a 2D action platformer with Warioware-style minigames. I don't really know what it is about games made by French developers, but from the ones I've played or at least watched (OFF, EYE: Divine Cybermancy), they feel really unique and/or experimental. Hell Yeah! definitely joins them as an experience. 

What I personally liked about Hell Yeah!'s dialog and presentation is that it felt like something straight from the period of time between 2005 and 2009 where websites like Newgrounds and SomethingAwful were thriving and 4-c-h-a-n was just exiting its infancy and all of those communities were producing original content. It's crass, over the top, nonsensical, feels a little like a Flash game, and is pretty damn fun.

[h1]Some positive things that stood out to me about Hell Yeah! were:[/h1]

- There wasn't a single mechanic that went either lightly used or completely unused. Even things as minute as zooming out a little bit were used as boss defeating/puzzle solving mechanics.

- The weapons were fun and varied and there weren't any hard limits on when the player could use their weapons.

- There were lots of nice silly customizations for the player to buy and slap on Ash and his blade-wheel jetpack.

- The environments allowed for some gameplay mixups: underwater levels had Ash in a submarine with torpedos and bombs, the space level had Ash in a spaceship, etc.

[h1]Some negative things that stood out:[/h1]

- Any time Ash was on foot was absolutely miserable. Double jumping and wall ricocheting couldn't make any of the on-foot segments fun.

- Some of the side missions are either unintuitive or just plain not fun (for those who played: the motocross missions in the casino, the "race the monster spirit" mission in the factory)

- "The Island" is useless. "The Island" is a gameplay element where the defeated minibosses can go perform odd tasks to serve Ash, like getting the player more money or health, or an unlock. In practice, the time it takes for any of the bonuses to accrue is really slow and by the time I was done with the game, got basically no mileage out of it.

- There's considerable backtracking and we as players don't get a teleport feature until the game is just about halfway done. I personally just liked exploring so it didn't feel too much like backtracking for me.

- I felt strapped for cash until around the halfway mark of the game, where I wanted to buy more health or upgraded weapon levels but there wasn't much to do except go find a miniboss or some treasure. I think the side missions can be repeated for cash, but I inevitably found myself loaded with cash after the halfway mark.

[h1]Closing thoughts:[/h1]

- The finishing move minigames "lasted" a surprisingly long time in terms of enjoyment. I started getting bored of them by the high 60s/mid 70s kill count on minibosses, and that's already about a third of the game.

- When you beat the final boss, stick around through the credits to see all the pictures. It's kinda humorous and the segment was a tell that the Arkedo team had a lot of fun bringing Hell Yeah! to life.

Hell Yeah! ran me about 8 hours. It's got a few DLC missions that supposedly tack on another 3, but I don't think I'd play them, honestly. This game is fine to play once and I wouldn't pay $15 for it. Maybe $10, but it goes on sale for $3.75 and that's a steal for 8 hours of goofy gorey fun.

71158492.review:
Hell Yeah! is, at first glance, fun, quirky action platformer in which you play as Ash, the recently appointed King of Hell. When some intimate pictures of Ash make their way to the Internet, Ash decides to find the one responsible, by killing every other inhabitant of Hell.

The gameplay itself is very reminiscent of classic platformers like Sonic, though rather than trying to finish each level as fast as possible, you need to find and kill specific monsters in each zone in order to progress; the game also has some metroidvania mechanics, as doors get unlocked after a certain number of monsters killed, and you can also get upgrades that allow you to access previously locked areas. The main appeal of the game would be the minibosses; killing them isn't as simple as shooting them until they die (or slashing them with your spinning saw), and once you bring their health down, you need to play a minigame in order to finish them off in a gorey explosion. While a cool mechanic at first, as you progress through the game it becomes increasingly annoying: if you fail the minigame, you get hurt instead, and some of them give you a very limited time to pull them off. Not to mention that draining the bosses' health down is a challenge to begin with. As you progress, you may acquire different weapons and upgrades from store, which is kinda cool to have more variety, but by the end of the game, I kept using a single weapon.

While the levels themselves (and the general aesthetics of the game) look pretty good with a cartoony style, the design itself isn't very good. There's many spikes scattered across some of the later levels that are a one-hit kill, not to mention other deadly traps. More often than not you'll end up dying not to a boss, but to one of those traps, and considering how scarce checkpoints are in some levels, you might lose a lot of progress when you die (the game does save each time you kill a miniboss, but when you die, it takes you back to the location of the last checkpoint).

I can say I enjoyed the game's soundtrack, in particular a couple of the songs. The aesthetics, as I mentioned above, are also very good, as are the references and jokes sprinkled through the game. However, there are many issues that I've mentioned and detracted from my overall enjoyment, which is why I can't recommend this game.

I tried to like this game, I really did, but after an hour it became near punishment to continue. The idea is fun and quite a nice throwback to classic Sega arcade games, over the top and 'zany', but it ends up boiling down all of the amusing parts of 90's EXTREME 'culture', leaving this steaming pile of a game. 
The camera movement is fast in a way that left everyone in the room queasy. Movements are inaccurate and the controller wont allow remapping (picking Zoom, which freezes the level, in place of the previous weapon button) which makes absolutely no sense. I wanted to like the juvenile humor but it was so erratic, yet blandy written, I would rather suck on a roll of toilet paper to be left with a better taste in my mouth. It contradicts itself with what it teaches you, to do one action, then the opposite without warning. 

The soundtrack consists of a few alternating 16 bar loops any eight year old could compose better in the trial version of FL studio, it leaves the player with the delightful experience analogous to chewing tinfoil. 

Overall, if you feel experiencing what presents itself as the results of a developer spending three days doing executive-cocaine off of discount prostitute's deflated cheeks, culminating in a brain hemorrhage-turned-game dev pitch, definitely buy this game. This is something you purchase for someone who's pooed on your carpet. My friends now doubt my judgement on game night.

It's a no from me, although for the first 1 hour 30 I would have more than recommended it.

Strange, innovative, quirky, not insanely difficult and well worth a sequel if the studio hadn't folded.  To start with.

Then it goes down the toilet by stripping you of your weapons and turning into as bad a game as Super Meat Boy leaving you with only your double jump wall running.

30 minutes to get past a very annoying boss being thrown around the screen by explosion knock back and mistimed perfect jumps, dying to be put back to the last checkpoint and the looping splash screen story pop up.  Again and again.

Things don't really improve after that with sudden death jumps that put you back to a save point to do easy bits again and again to get to the sudden death jump. To die. Again.

Coupled with introducing unique game mechanics that aren't explained or used again, without a youtube walkthrough I would never have been able to complete it at many points.

Neither are your fault, it is just a hang over of bad level design, gameplay and a lack of explaning or introducing game mechanics that existed back in 2012, thankfully games design has moved on since to eliminate many of these problems.

The level design reminds me of Deadlight, although not as bad and I did not finish it as I gave up near the end.

It becomes increasingly obscure and tedious and I just couldn't be bothered.  Along with the other 91.6% of owners.

Overall - a remake or a sequel now could really unlock what this game could of been, but as it is it is pretty tortuous and obscure to play.

Comments are off because i would expect proponents of this game as it became from chapter 3 - and probably Super Meat Boy fans - to have nothing more to say than git gud nub.

59724513.review:
I'm not quite sure how to describe this game in a way that makes sense, so I'm just going to post some unconnected comments.

So, the basic plot of this game is: you are a skeletal rabbit who's in charge of hell. Some pervert took candid nudie pics of you in the bathtub with your rubber ducky. He's distributed them on the hellternet, and you're determined to track down every last denizen of hell who's seen the pics and murder them. Again.

You know how in Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow, there's a system where, after depleting a boss's health bar, you need to use the stylus on the DS touch screen to draw a special symbol, to actually beat the boss? What if, instead of drawing a symbol, you had to complete a bizarre, Warioware-esque minigame to trigger the boss's defeat, which also plays a unique execution animation for every boss? It'd be AWESOME, that's what.

In Sonic the Hedgehog, you have these spring platforms which bounce you upwards, right? Well, in this game, they're green butts that you bounce on, and make fart noises when you do.

The gameplay is sorta Metroidvania-esque, but not truly. Most of the time, your character drives around in a sawblade contraption, armed with heavy weaponry. That's pretty ridiculous. There's a surprising amount of unique artwork and animations - every boss/mini-boss has a unique sprite, and a unique minigame (with a couple repeats), and a unique death animation. There's also a bestiary that keeps track of each one. It's got a great sense of humor, with references and shout-outs to plenty of other media, which I always appreciate. The music is catchy, the graphics bright and colorful, and the gameplay enjoyable. There is a lot of gore, but it's in an over-the-top, cartoony way. Like Tom and Jerry, with buckets more blood.

In short, it's one of the most ridiculous games, with one of the most ridiculous plots, I've ever played, but it's highly enjoyable and polished. You can tell while playing it that the developers really cared about it, and knew what they were doing. Recommended.

54602552.review:
Guns, blood, and an eerily cute undead rabbit; this is the recipe for Hell Yeah! In Hell, souls are doomed to eternal torment over minor squabbles. When Ash discovers that tabloids have posted compromising pictures of him with his favorite rubber ducky, seven worlds and over one hundred monsters are no match for his wrath. While Ash might look like nothing more than bones and a cape, he is infact the Prince of Hell. His arsenal is comparable to that of the average Contra or Metal Slug. He also tears through both earth and adversary alike while riding a giant buzz-saw.

When you stack a bunch of awesome-sounding things on top of one another, you expect something truly incredible. However, after I completed the game, I only felt indifference. My blood never boiled, my (lack of) muscles didn’t tense up, and I never once gritted my teeth. In fact, I felt like I never played a videogame. Hell Yeah! is more like a series of interactive events. There is some platforming, a bit of shooting, but all that manages to stick out are the dozens of minigames and QTEs. Maybe I’m taking the wrong approach. Perhaps Hell Yeah! is actually an adventure game, where aspects such as challenge and replay-value aren’t necessary. Wait... that sounds like a lame excuse, doesn't it?

Progressing through Hell is quite simple, kill enough monsters and doors will open, which allows Ash to move on. Killing these monsters doesn’t always require bullets or explosives. Occasionally, heavy objects have to be dropped on their heads, or their death is the result of some puzzle-solving. When a monster is depleted of its health a mini-game follows. Succeed and the monster dies, fail and Ash takes some damage. The way I see it, now the well has been sufficiently poisoned. More than anything else, I hate QTEs and by extension mini-games, especially when they’re required just to kill something.  Every time a mini-game is successfully completed, Ash finishes the monster off in some grand fashion. It is kind-of like playing Mortal Kombat, except you have to use fatalities to win. Seeing these finishing moves is neat the first time, but they repeat and can’t be skipped.

When Ash dies, he’s kicked back to the last checkpoint. While Hell Yeah! couldn’t find difficulty on a map, a bad checkpoint is liable to be the cause of most deaths. If Ash takes a lot of damage in an area, that’s going to carry over to the next checkpoint he triggers. This can be frustrating, especially since this game has rather sloppy controls. Yeah, since Ash’s sweet ride is essentially a wheel; that means there is going to be a bit of sliding around. This makes jumping over spike-pits more trouble than it should be. There are a couple instances where Ash has to run around sans weapons and wheel. Maybe the wheel should have just been dropped altogether. Ash is easier to control when he’s not driving a vehicle. 

Exploring each world leads to the acquisition of money, which can then be spent on new guns and upgrades. This money can also be used towards the “pimp out your dead rabbit”. A fair amount of my enjoyment with this game has come from finding and purchasing new hairdos and helmets for Ash.  Some of the purchasable weapons like the shotgun are pretty cool, but the rest I struggled to find a use for. 

There is little in the way of extra content. Side missions can be done for a little more cash and wigs. Also, all monsters that Ash kills are shipped off to The Island. Here they are put to work on various tasks for Ash’s benefit. Unfortunately their labor really wasn’t any help to me. By the time I completed the game, no discoveries were made, and all the monsters had done was cooked something that restored 30 points of health.  On the bright side, it is slightly entertaining watching these fiends walk around.
Where Hell Yeah! excels is in the audiovisual department. The worlds are vivid, surreal, and diverse. All of the monsters are unique and creatively drawn. The music is fantastic and the sound-design is great. I would almost recommend playing through the game, just to see and hear everything firsthand. Ultimately this makes for a fine experience, which is suitable for an adventure game.

With a title like Hell Yeah! there’s really only one word I can use to describe it: in-offensive. This is the type of game, where all of its note-worthy aspects, require the least amount of effort to appreciate. This isn’t like a fighting game, where someone would spend hundreds of hours practicing and training just to understand the depth it can hold. Actually I can’t even say that this title would be comparable to other platformers like Sonic Generations, where at least some skill is required to attain a better score. Finding enjoyment in this game is tied to your expectations. If all you want to do is a burn up a weekend in a charming but shallow adventure, then by all means give this game a go. If you’re looking for something that you’ll actually want to replay and get better at, I could point you towards thousands of games that are better than Hell Yeah!

53518992.review:
You got some metroidvania platformer elements, upgrades and such, using that control scheme I wish was more popular with mouse-aim and wasd. And it's all done with an edgy cartoony humor.

This game is a bunch of cool ideas mashed together in a way that isn't broken or anything that severe, but it is uninspired at best and incohesive at its worst. Like it was made by a committee, or commissioned to a talented team that just wasn't in the mood for doing this. It checks all the boxes but with a minimum effort to call it done.

I can see where they were going with the humor and style. It's like Max from Sam&Max, but not as funny and endearing. It's has over the top violence like [choose one of the infinite examples] and it has its moments. I  particularly enjoyed the shark missile from orbit while playing classical music. But it was the only moment that its over the top violence made me smile.

The gameplay is interesting in theory. The worst problem of the game, in my opinion, is that mouse+wasd works for levels designed for mouse+wasd, not for typical platforming. This is where the game design starts to fall apart. I like aiming with the mouse but it really doesn't seem all that relevant in how the enemies and levels are designed. Sometimes enemies are slightly above you, or moving above, and mouse aim makes sense. But it's not fun to play with my left hand and only occasionally moving the cursor to shoot something that is usually directly in front of me. And then the game goes as far as to take the guns away on certain levels, effectively making my right hand useless. And I swear, some parts of the game require some serious platforming skills, designed to use your right hand on arrows and left for jumping, or a controller. Meanwhile we have to play tricky platforming with only our left hands.

No, the mouse aim thing does not click with how the rest of the game was designed. Maybe during prototyping the game it was a traditional platformer with shooting in four directions with a dpad and the devs decided to jam in mouse aim and tweak the rest of the game (poorly). This is my best bet. Games designed from the ground up with mouse aim and platforming don't suffer from the problems I'm seeing here. Games like Abuse focus more on combat and movement is simpler compared to traditional platformers in order to balance the workload of movement and shooting.

Anyway, do I recommend playing Hell Yeah? Hell No! ok, maybe 'hell no' is a bit too strong but I needed to say that. It's more of a "meh, I don't think so".

52048704.review:
This is one of those games which I have probably gotten in a bundle sometime in the past but did not play until much later and honestly I was not sure what I was expecting, if there is a list of games that are "so bad, it's good", this would be among them.

Hell Yeah! is a game about an axe crazy dead(?) rabbit on a rampage after he gets called a p*ssy for having an affection for rubber ducks. Also, you're the prince of Hell, you know, the afterlife. Killing enemies makes about as much sense as you think.

The presentation is definitely one of the game's strong points. The absurdist Hell setting with single line backstory enemies complete with WarioWare-esque minigames and ridiculous death animations certainly give a game a strong identity. Unfortunately, the game does feel as though it spreads itself rather thin. There are 100 main enemies you have to defeat albeit no where near as many special death animations, some designs end up being pretty bland overall. The music also ranges from disappointingly mediocre to hilariously bad.

Unfortunately, the gameplay does not really hold up compared to the presentation. The game is in essence a linear platformer with shooting. Most of the game is played on a sawblade drill with an attached jetpack and heavy weaponry (don't question it), with some pure platforming segments as well as some vehicle segments. There is enough gameplay variety to hold up a 10-hour game but none of the gameplay styles are executed very well. At least the overall low difficulty meant that I rarely got frustrated.

Would I recommend Hell Yeah? I don't know. It is very much not the type of game that I expected to enjoy let alone finish. I suppose it is easy to recommend if you are looking for a game that is quite literally "So bad, it's good" given there aren't a lot of games like that. Oh, and if you're looking for how much crap you can get past the radar with a T rating, it is also an excellent choice.

[h1]In-Depth:[/h1]
Hell Nah! is a boss rush game with very lighthearted humor and a neat art style. Both of these end up getting quite annoying as you soon realise what this game is all about.

At first I really enjoyed the overall style and the death scenes of the bosses, which seemed unique at the time. The problems became apparent quite soon, as the game turned frustrating because of unskippable dialogue, a mess of a map that becomes quite hard to navigate making you lose track of where and what you were doing and even switching weapons became a clunky and tedious process.

Some levels felt straight up unfair while others were boring, this was emphasized in the bonus levels where they were either mindless challenges or nigh impossible ones for whatever reason. You cannot change your settings and sadly the controls can suck a lot for some minigames, which can mean life or death in some scenarios.

The credits were unskippable and the jackpot achievement was a complete waste of time. (use cheat engine to speed up the game 20x - not over as it will break it, or use a script for this one)

51167293.review: Entertaining, in a dumb fun sort of way. Very imaginative in some aspects.

51050020.review:
Well, I only gave it half an hour but I probably won't be playing any more. That should tell you everything.

The main issue that I found was... it's boring, actually. It's not that it's too easy or too hard, or they don't give you enough or too much to do, Hell Yeah! just isn't fun. Like they forgot to work the hardest on the thing you do the most of: just moving around.

So, it's just a pretty typical sidescrolling platforming metroidvania. There's a Farmville kinda mobile game attached to it aside from the running and shooting, which just seems kind of weird. You press WASD to run around and if you press spacebar you do this weird extended jump, I think it's meant to be some kind of jetpack (according to the game) but it feels like you're just jumping really high since you don't have a 'jetpack meter' or whatever.

'Ash' (the skeleton bunny you play as) controls okay, but he's a little slippery and as I said before it's not really very fun moving around. You don't get any sense of momentum, you accelerate up to your maximum run speed in about half a second. It's not bad, it's just a little off.

The guns, at least the ones I should stress I saw in the first thirty minutes, are pretty boring. You get a rocket launcher and a machine gun, nothing special and they don't really sound or feel good to use, they don't sound chunky like they should. Also, I noticed the machine gun seems to be firing whole bullets... maybe some Cave Johnson magic. Considering the oversaturation of effects elsewhere I'm also a little disappointed you don't drop spent casings with every shot, it'd be a nice little touch. Your guns don't recharge their meters (guns don't have ammo counts, just a recharging meter) unless they're out which kind of means instead of doing your utmost to burn through all your ammo reserves by cycling through each one you might as well pick whichever does the most damage and just... wait.

Everything to do with graphics and visuals is busy as all hell, to the point where sometimes you just sorta look at the screen and go "uh, what am I looking at here?" and while that doesn't bother me too much now I feel like it'd probably get on my nerves after a while. I played almost the full 30 minutes without realizing what my health bar was, since there's no explanation of anything on your HUD and it's somewhat unconventional (your HP is this weird zigzag down the left side of the screen, like Harry Potter but less obvious).

It's sad though that I actually think the game looks pretty good. Like compared to some of the indie trash being pushed out today it makes me wonder where everything went so wrong. Hell Yeah! is actually pretty reasonably polished, maybe something to do with SEGA publishing but I have no idea (how did they con SEGA into this?)

Ultimately, Hell Yeah! kind of feels like a Newgrounds game. There's no positives about that, not really. Everything about it is 'retarded' and I can't think of a word that represents the sensation this game gives me better. This game is retarded. It is as stupid and dumb as possible and appeals to the audience exclusively on those merits. Everything about it is dated, sort of like the Gex games, but not quite as charming.

Please buy anything that isn't this with your $15.

This game sometimes gets a lot of criticism for different reasons but I think it's not fair to be harsh on a game that doesn't take itself too seriously.
This game is in some sense, a parody of different games and popular memes.

+ The gameplay is fluid and there are many weapons to use.
+ The visuals are vibrant, colorful and the environments are pretty.
+ Many skins for the head, body and your blade to choose from.
+ Too many references of different media
+ Sometimes really humorous and funny if you let it be
+ Music is awesome
+ Many challenge missions to do post-game
+ Some clever puzzles in there
+ The Island is a nice feature of making monsters working for you to produce gifts and items for story mode.

- Bosses death cutscenes can be redundant and boring after seeing them many times.
- Some mini-games require a ridiculous key combination such as pressing F + X + E + Space at the same time.
- Can be considered either as too edgy or stupid

Overall: 8.5/10 - a very fun 2D platformer

47162965.review:
Hell yeah! is quite an enjoyable platformer.  

Pros - 
- Bright, beautiful cartoon quality graphics
- a distinct identity
- an idiosyncratic sense of humour (although it missed the mark with me personally)
- a catchy soundtrack
- Expansive levels
- enjoyably wacky boss fight mini-games that might have been inspired by Nintendo's Warioware games

Cons
- slippy, slidy controls which result in some truly frustrating insta-death situations
- Very, very easy
- underdeveloped gameplay mechanics (weaponary teleport system, boss fights are present but don't really add much to the game)
 
Overall, the game has enough charm, variety, humour and personality to compensate for its superficial game design. Not a classic, but an enjoyable and worthwhile experience.

44533624.review:
Hell Yeah! is just wasted potential. It really could have been a great game, but there are way to many design flaws. First, the controls are floaty and platforming does not feel satsfying at all. Second, there is no depth to the game, everything is very surface level. The weapons, while different, all perform about the same and you rarely ever find a situation where you should use one weapon over another. This makes all the upgrades feel irrelevant. Third, adding to the the surface level depth, "The Island" is a big waste of time. At first glance it looks really interesting, with all of the different locations, but after 2 minutes messing with it, you realize everything there could and should be condensed into one tab. It is really a shame too, because there a so many art assets in this game. Which brings me to my next point.

The art assets. I actually really enjoyed the art style. It has 100 unique monsters, tons of detail in each of the levels and there is a lot of cosmetic character customization. This bothers me a lot, since visually, the game really does pop out, but of course, without solid gameplay, the art is just wasted. I feel like they wanted to do some sort of "Pokemon" theme with the way that you can collect the monsters you defeat on "The Island" but maybe budget cuts forced them to simplify it. Lastly, I found the humor to be servicable; a little bit childish, but funny enough. 

Overall, I cannot recommend this game, especially at the current $15 price tag. If you are really interested then I would say wait for it to be sold at $2 or less. Ah, and one more thing. There is not an option for the sound... why would you not implement that? This game is published by SEGA and they just chose to omit that setting?

43779256.review:
[b]Pros[/b]
+60FPS
+Over the top humor
+Fun art-style
+Some good music tracks
+Generally fun to play

[b]Cons[/b]
+Controls are not the best (see above paragraph)
+Slightly repetitive towards the end
+No invincibility time after getting hit
+Questionable hitboxes
+Can’t skip dialog or boss death scenes

This is quite a fun 2D platformer. Once you see the plot, you quickly understand this game is based around humor. Simple mechanics and controls that are made for the 360 controller. They keyboard controls are [b]terrible[/b]. I would consider playing with a controller an absolute must.

Gameplay is pretty straight forward. Platforming with smaller enemies to kill and various obstacles in your way. To progress in the game you must kill the “bosses” (there are 100 of them). I put bosses in quotes as they are easy to defeat. After you drain their health, you have to play a short mini-game. These games are funny and usually last 5-10 seconds.

You get money for killing bosses and for collecting the random jewels and skulls. This can be used to buy weapon upgrades, life bonuses, new hats, etc. This does get a little repetitive in the last 25% of the game, but was still enjoyable due to them not being too tough. 

You get a good progression tracking system. The full map will show how complete each level is, how many monsters are left and how many side missions remain. Also, there’s a radar on your HUD that shows where the next monster (boss) is for the current level.

One strange area is “The Island”. This is where the bosses go after you defeat them. They can work on getting you any one of 4 rewards that transfer to your campaign. A boss can get sad or angry after working for a bit, so you have to send them to their appropriate places to become happy again. Even for this game, it’s bizarre why this even exists.

The controls need some work.
-Twitchy movement with small controller stick input. I died from this numerous times
-Wall jump tied to holding “A” button which is also the jump button. This leads to bouncing off a wall when you just wanted to double jump up to it normally.
-Jumping and trying to shoot at the same time is awkward.
 


Even with the cons listed, my first sentence in this review still stands. It’s a fun game. It was clear to me that this was built to be played to the end and enjoyed. Certainly recommended, but the asking price is a bit high. 

[b]6/10[/b] Above Average

43615823.review:
What is Hell Yeah!: Wrath of the Dead Rabbit ?

I was really conflicted about my overall thoughts about this game, I didnt know if I would recommend it or not, I wasn't 100% sure of the final verdict but after a few thoughts I had I came to a conclusion, I do not think that Hell Yeah! is an actual good game overall that does most of its stuff pretty well or introduces something unique, its decent/average, it tries to have a humor but I felt it was pretty weak, despite having a nice artstyle which Imo looked very detailed and just made the game look beautiful as hell, I never felt interested into the world or characters they built here, most stuff, even the story felt forced, the main point should be the gameplay and for a while it was good, they built here a fine gameplay loop but it gets repetitive too easily ill explain that below...

Hell Yeah! is a simple 2d platformer game with decents ammount of action and a few backtracking elements that reminds me of a few metroidvania games but its not really a full metroidvania, you get different levels that you can move through teleportation devices and your objective is simple, you have 101 demons to kill in order to show youre some sort of badass demon villain, to do this you have this buzzsaw vehicle that has a jetpack and different guns to use, the game has a decent ammount of guns but most of them feels the same, theres no different tactics when it comes using them and every demon was already easy enough, its not like they posed a threat or change of style during the fights, all you do is shooting them until they HP reaches zero and a minigame games which is either something simplistic as controlling a bus avoiding crashes or QTEs, since its repeated 101 times through the game and many minigames are reused it get so old, repetitive, overused and boring, this game would have benefited if it was slightly shorter, I felt that the gameplay overstayed its welcome they even try to introduce a few new mechanics or one-time ideas to keep it fresh but all they do is fuck the pacing of the game up, we even get a completely worthless management minigame here that you barely have a reason to use at all, the game has some underveloped ideas and a mentality of throwing many stuff at once on a wall to see what sticks on it, the result at the end is just a decent but troubled game that can be fun in some occasiations, considering I got this game for free from one of SEGA's giveaway packs which came with a bunch of other games and I had a bit of fun and theres a few qualities here mostly the soundtrack, art style and the first half of the game I had more [i]Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit[/i] is an action platformer metroidvania chock full of references to other videogames. It doesn't heavily rely on its very flimsy plot to keep you entertained (because it doesn't need to, plot's unnecessary when you have fun mechanics), it does that with its consistent gameplay.

40266437.review:
Don't get me wrong. Hell Yeah is not a bad game, but its not anything special either.  
Why? Hear me out

Somewhere in Hell, lives a rabbit who is for some weird reason is the ruler of Hell. One night he takes a bath with his water duck, when suddenly a paparatis take a picture of him with his duck. This embarrassing photo is then spread all through Hell, forcing your rabbit ruler to go on a crazy killing spree.

In Hell Yeah your goal is to kill as many monsters as possible. You shoot the living hell out of them, then you are presented with a minigame in which you have to time buttons, or smash them. At first it was a fun idea, but after doing it a while it starts to feel repetitive. This is the main issue with the game. It sounds and look decent and some of the ideas are interessting, but after the first two hours you allready feeling the repetitivenes. Track down a monster through mazes of platforming, then kill them, then find more monster to kill in order to proseesd to the next area. It is a decent game to play on a low sepc system, and runs great. If you like platforming I would say you could give it a change on a %50 off sale.

39580326.review:
This game makes a strong first impression, but the more time you spend with it the more disappointing it turns out to be. You can see a hell of a lot of creativity went into it, from the 101 unique monsters and the art which is great throughout. The music is also good, though repetitive. The writing is quite funny, with a tone that comes across as "knowingly edgy"... but nearer the end you wonder if it's actually that knowing. 

The gameplay is the serious weak link and the game really falls down because of it.  Each monster seems to have their own unique minigame but as you progress you see that is not the case, and every 5 or so monsters are defeated the same way. Tracking down each monster becomes pretty tedious, and there are only two real boss fights. Platforming difficulty feels artificial because of the awkward, slippery controls and physics, and one-hit-kill spikes which are a cheap-and-cheerful way to ramp up difficulty. Those spikes will kill you more times than any of the monsters.

Beating the game yields the incriminating photos you were tracking down, which are creative but not funny enough to pay off. The DLC and post-game content takes the form of more missions, which I didn't have the heart to complete because I couldn't stand interacting with the control system any more. 

Reviewers generally decided this game was all style and no substance, and they're about right. I'd probably recommend watching a speedrun of this game rather than playing it, so you can witness the great art and music without the tedious gameplay. Arkedo's next game, "Poof", got marginally better scores so I assume they have learned some lessons from this one.

Sorry guys... I can't recommend this game. About half the time it is fun, and you'll like it. However, there are many situations where the mechanics will make you want to blow your brains out after doing it for the twentieth time. So many times in the game, if you don't jump exactly perfectly then you die and have to start over every single time. Checkpoints are inconvenient, healing is annoying, and weapons are okay. 

Also get used to seeing cutscenes EVERY SINGLE TIME if you die. Stuck on a hard boss or enemy monster? You'll have their whole dialogue memorized by the time you beat it. Can't beat that monster because you didn't jump perfectly or accidentally touched one of the many 1-hit kill obstacles? Get ready for the game to show you that thing you use to kill the monster EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. It's about 40% fun, 60% infuriating gameplay for me.

36035765.review:
Hell no.

I REALLY wanted to like this game. It basically seemed to advertise itself as a combination of jazzy jackrabbit: a game I adored as a little child, and, well, METAL, a thing I adore always. 

...but it is so... ...Lacking in teeth. 

No weapons feel like they have any impact. Or enemies. the music doesn't get your blood pumping: it doesn't even really register. the environments aren't threatening, nor are they campy. they're just... uninspired. 

...if anyone who made it happens to read this, and to any potential buyers, too:
I think you had a great idea here, I really do. But the problem is you never took the gloves off. It should have been... well, METAL. Head banging, blood spurting, gore-smashing, iron-clashing, riff-djenting, METAL. It should have been brutal. That doesn't mean it has to be unhappy: you can totally do funny and delightful METAL. But it needs to have teeth. heart. soul. and while I'm sure you put a lot of effort into it--because I can see the overall product is well polished-- it feels like you were holding back out of fear of getting an M rating or something. ...embrace the M rating. Or don't even get rated. Just make the game you want to make, and make it fun. make it with teeth. 

getting back to potential buyers: ...it isn't BAD. it really isn't. it's fully functional, it's fine.

but that's kinda my point. is that it's fine, when it should have been goofy and ridiculous and self depricating and wild, instead it's... well, tame. tame, not lame. it is fine, just fine. and that's the problem.

but if you enjoyed the ad vids etc: you'll probably enjoy the game. but if you were looking for the METAL version of Jazzy Jackrabbit like me? this isn't it, sadly.

...however, I do think, if they take the advice above, a sequel could be pretty friggin sick. 

I hope they get the chance to try again and pleasantly surprise me :)

but for now, from me personally: no. 

but I fully admit I think it is a taste-based recommendation, not mechanics etc. the game itself as a program is perfectly functional. but it... well. read above. So base your call on taste, not function, because the function is fine and dandy.

35625287.review:
The rabbit prince of hell is snapped playing with a rubber duck whilst having a bath. After being shamed for "being a pussy" he sets out on a bloody path to redeem his macho rep, and get the incriminating photo's.

So begins a rather stupid side scrolling shooter, with a bizarre sense of humour that veers between moderately amusing and slightly tedious.

This is a passable game with the odd bit of decent action, but its still a million miles away from beating the genre greats. The shooting and platforming elements are a bit loose, and though the controls are responsive the intensity just isn't there.

Its enjoyable for the most part, but it won't exactly leave you in a sweat with your heart pounding. There's some annoying bits where you won't be too sure what it is you have to do, as it has a mild puzzle element in places. 

Though I find it commendable that its not totally braindead, these bits can be  a bit obtuse and / or fiddly. Its not a bad game, nor is it a great one, but if you find it in a sale its worth a look.

34639524.review:
I don't recommend supporting Sega. Even buying their good games supports bad practices. Hell Yeah is just passable.

If you don't care whether you support DRM that may repeatedly force you online for re-validation; or make games that use it eventually cease to work for all legitimate owners; or you only care about this particular piece of software then it's safe to ignore the preamble & "score" of this review. I believe the rest of its contents are fair criticism.

Buying any of Sega's products, even older ones that lack that DRM like this one does, will support the inclusion of said DRM in future products. As someone who does a lot of gaming offline I can't support a company which does that.

If that doesn't bother you, again, feel free to ignore my preamble and "score".
---

Hell Yeah is a perfectly functional game, though I've heard that on PS3 it was too unstable to even claim that much, but it's almost surprising how forgettable it is. Other than the intentionally aggravating "cute world" (you'll know when you find it) most of the rest of the game kind of blends together.

It's technically a Metroidvania if those are your thing but it's a very linear one with surprisingly few secrets to find. It's more like a collection of mini-Metroidvanias like Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia. Don't take that as a recommendation though. It's not nearly as good or as polished mechanically.

There's very little incentive to keep playing after you beat it.

Most of its sense of humor isn't to my taste but if you like references to things then maybe you'll laugh at all the references to things.

I get the feeling the game was considered for a mobile release. "The Island" """minigame""" works like a lot of f2p games with a ton of real time waiting minus the ability to pay real money to speed anything up or upgrade things. Maybe it's supposed to be a parody of f2p games but in practice it just "plays" like a real one.

There are some (unimportant) rewards like certain outfits you can only get by messing with it & it's best to set it up ASAP if you intend to touch it at all because Hell Yeah is such a short game that otherwise you can beat it without even unlocking your first reward from it.

The dev went defunct not long after the game launched so I doubt you'd be supporting them if you buy it.

There's little wrong with the game itself so it could be worth a look for 2D platforming fans during a sale; however Sega did give the game away for free at one point (I paid for it) so I find it hard to believe there's many in its target audience who haven't already played it.

33709432.review:
Overall it's a 65% game.

You get a Jazz Jackrabbit style level runner with some shooting and weapon choices along the main plot of defeating enemies and that's as much as there needs to be said about the game's core design. The bosses in the game are just weird in their appearance. The levels vary. The game has a very direct and partially dark humor that I couldn't get in touch with much. Killing a boss forces the player to perform a finisher, otherwise the boss restores some health and the character receives damage as if hit. Those finishers may be something new and unique but imo they weren't required and not making them optional but forcing them on the player was a mistake, especially since they get repetitive after some time. Devs: Just because you think a feature is cool don't force it on the players. They may not like it, they may not always be in the mood for it, allow the players to decide how to enjoy the game more.

Mixed feelings on the controls. Imo using one button for two distinct actions (jump & wall jump) led to an inaccuracy of what action is to perform and accidental mistakes as result. The character also tends to slide a little until stopping which led to falling down numerous times for me. Should imo slide only at high speed but not anymore when at walking / slow running speed but just stop.

The enemies require a certain approach to be defeated, which the player needs to figure out to succeed. This can lead to being stuck. An example for this is the boss "Irish" who requires the player action of zooming the view / camera out to kill the boss. Another example are the smoking creates in one of the other levels that require to shoot the smoke so that it catches fire and damages objects above it, even through the ceiling. The game doesn't make that clear. Enemy projectiles also tend to come from off-screen and most often can be fully evaded. Yet player projectiles are deleted once the leave the screen and thus always have less range then enemy projectiles and are unreliable to hit if being mobile and I guess that was a design decision to make sure the player doesn't snipe enemies from the corners of the screen. For boss fights there rarely may be situations in which a boss becomes immune to damage. Games like Megaman had the *glows red* indicator to make that clear. This game just doesn't give any hint for any immunity on / off. You have to know and guess but it's only a very minor issue. Enemies may also move inside the level's terrain sometimes, rendering them unkillable as they can't be hit while inside the terrain.

In the game world I sometimes had trouble realizing that some of the darker objects weren't just background objects but actual movement blocking main world objects.

The economy to upgrade gear and buy new stuff is about gathering coins and gems. Aside from that money can be gained by boss kills, missions, slot machines and "the island", with slot machines breaking the economy: I made so much money there that I didn't have to worry about anything for the rest of the game.

A strange economy, research and upgrade objects is "the island": Bosses you defeat are sent to that place to work for you. You can assign them to 1 of 4 tasks but what these actually do to which effect / degree in the game I haven't figured out yet because this feature isn't explained at all and any bit while also not being accessible from within the current game. Instead to access "the island" you have to quit your current game, go to the main menu, access "the island" from there to make your settings and then you can continue with your regular game. Imo that made it into the game too late and lacks an actual use.

Within the levels there are reusable checkpoints. Usually autosaves also happen after defeating a boss but not always. This leads to issues:
If dying after gathering money / items from hard to get areas and before being able to save that'll have to be done again. Because checkpoints are sometimes very far away and there are enemies and obstacles to avoid to get to them that can be burden just for saving progress.
Another issues is with boss fights where saves didn't happen and repetitive, unskippable dialogue and after succeeding forced finishers again.

I finished the game and all it's missions in one run and I doubt I'll be playing it again. While I didn't dislike it I also can't say I really enjoyed it but that it's been one weird trip. What kept me playing were the game's core mechanics that worked but imo other games I have are more enjoyable at that. If I could I'd give this game a clear mediocre rating but with only the decisions of recommended or not remaining I wouldn't recommend it even though I didn't encounter any bugs and it's well playable.

Issues for me:
-double binding of wall jump & jump (one other button pressed to make use of wall jump would've been more accurate)
-unreliable projectiles: player projectiles being deleted off-screen
-broken economy (slot machine)
-badly integrated "the island"
-lack of explaination where it was necessary (camera zoom out; how to access "the island"; what anything on "the island" does or any progress or anything there)
-instead of making the character invulnerable for a very short amount of time after being hit the character remains vulnerable and is pushed back a large distance, leading to unavoidable being hit chains at times
-projectiles don't accelerate with the player's movement
-weird bosses instead of functionally interesting bosses (most of the time)
-forced finishers
-no "skip" for dialogues
-some weapons are just the same as others and aren't really needed (should be upgrade paths of one weapon instead of carrying very similar ones around)
-clunky save & healing mechanic (sometimes had to run back a large distance just to gain health back and/or save); manual saves every x minutes and a slot regeneration would've done much to combat this
-a lot of new gear but aside from wall jump (only usable in areas with gear restriction) no new / advanced character abilities

Good:
-no bugs encountered
-most often level design and soundtrack
-core mechanics work
-upgrading makes things interesting
-the game allows to figure out how to deal with enemies (but should tell if it's not about combat and explain all non-combat things)
-good key bindings (aside from that jump / wall jump double use)
-tendency of weapon mechanics but sadly not fully eplored
-map (but should show items within explored areas)
-teleporters to avoid huge travel distances

33577845.review:
The technical implementation of this 2D platformer is quite solid, which is unusual for most 2D platformers.

Controls are a little lacking but don't get in the way of playing the game. 

The game art and design style is aimed at being "edgy cartoon over the top hyperviolence and gore for kids to enjoy".   Maybe kids really like this kind of thing, but I doubt it.   

Ultimately the graphics are just too noisy to get a good feel for what's going on.   This distracts from the game rather than enhancing it, and the continual loud imagery becomes an annoyance.  It's very close to being a thumbs up, but the game itself is lacking fun, while having put in a lot of effort trying to achieve it.   The game fails to hit the right notes, and comes out like a great rock band playing with instruments out of tune.   

Definitely not worth the $17.50 they want for the whole package.
