32823448.review:
El juego trata de que al prota le han robado unas fotos y 100 monstruos las han visto, así que tienes que ir a cargártelos a todos.

Es un plataformas con un [b]buen humor negro[/b] (a veces algo insulso, pero tiene algún diálogo/escena bueno) y una [b]buena variedad de armas y mundos[/b] que iremos desbloqueando poco a poco.

[b]¿Que por qué no lo recomiendo?[/b] Aquí un listado de razones:

· [b]Está mal escalado a 1080p[/b], causando que se vea algo [b]borroso[/b].

· [b]Las ejecuciones están guapas y los minijuegos son originales, pero al final se acaban repitiendo y haciéndose cansinas.[/b] Lo peor es que [b]no puedes saltarte las animaciones.[/b]

· [b]Controles malos y tramos mal programados para que tragues daño sí o sí.[/b]

· [b]Sistema de checkpoints muy mal ubicado.[/b]

· [b]Superrepetitivo y coñazo.[/b] El juego solo trata de avanzar e ir cargándote monstruos de la forma más cansina  posible.

· [b]"La Isla" es un alicente completamente inútil[/b], y encima ubicado en el menú principal, obligándonos a salir de la  partida.

· [b]Las misiones secundarias son escasas, están ocultas y son completamente prescindibles[/b] (a no ser que quieras el logro)

· [b]Duración entre 6-8 horas[/b] para pasárselo con todos los DLCs (aunque te parecerán 20h de lo pesado que es). Creo que la  duración lo contaría como una ventaja.

Y eso es todo, el juego al principio te impresiona por su estilo artístico y humor, pero te dura poco la ilusión.

32739827.review:
Im giving this a thumbs down, not in the way that the game is horrible and should be avoided but in more of a "There are quite a few better games on steam you should probably be playing first" way. 

This game isn't nearly as action packed as the trailers make it seem, in fact most of these trailers are nothing but finisher cut scenes. Game play is mostly slow and methodical platforming ala metroidvania but it doesn't really have any meat on the maps sans few areas. Most of the maps (especially the second half of the game) are more corridors to "mini-bosses" or puzzles to kill said mini bosses.  These Mini bosses are usually meh affairs or vehicles for jokes. Some you literally just walk up to and shoot, some are puzzles which range from ok to meh, you get a couple of big bosses but nothing to write home about. 

The weirdest thing is probably the mini games to beat each mini boss. Now, if each boss had one of these the pertained the themselves then we would be good. But it repeats the same 12 or so games and by half game they become more time wasters then charming game mechanics. 

TL:DR
There is a long list of games on steam you should be playing first before this game.

32223723.review:
Yes, the visuals are nicely done, the game looks cute and I like its soundtrack and silly humor.

But I just can't recommend this game to any serious player. 

This game is badly designed, plain and simple.

The controls are okay-good on a gamepad, but borderline dumb on a keyboard, you get the mouse advantage and that's it.

The missions are easily the worst part of the game for me, they seem so rushed and done to "add more content to the game" that it's obvious how flawed they are.
For starters, you don't have much mission variety, pick some coins, get from point A to B, kill X enemies... all with a time limit.

The problem is the map is not prepared for those missions, they are so luck-reliant that it hurts. Want to win that race in Factory? Not as long the green goo fountain activates as soon you reach it, or the platforms are in the opposite side at the start, you just need to have the luck to get everything so you can cross at the start, otherwise your opponent (who is a ghost) will win 95% of the times.

The game shows care and laziness in some parts of the game, you can see they clearly did a great effort about the monsters, giving them stories and things, the visuals are really well done as I said, that was a great part of the game.

In other hand, the luck factor and the occasional BS death or falling in spikes is about as much challenge this game is going to give you. Every monster/boss is easy, their AI is really basic, altough there are a lot of weapons there is not any difference between them but fire rate, damage, ammo and design. The grenades are seriously OP 

I hate how this game relies so much in Quicktime Events to the point that is literally a core mechanic of the game. They are unneeded, feel forced, and are no fun at all after doing the same QTE 10 times. Death animations get old pretty fast too.

You can tell this was not a game going for an amazing plot, but if you take away the subpar plot, the QTE and the badly implemented missions, all the fun you are going to get from the game is figuring how you are going to defeat some monsters (only some, because most are just shooting them).

After that, the postgame content are just even more missions and to be honest I left the game after getting all the achievements, there is no fun at all in 100% it when the missions are so bad (and I haven't talked about the Handle your Fuel mission in Cute Land where you are given no indications whatsoever as where the goal is and only a few seconds) and zones appear to not be complete for some weird reason (they all linger at about 90%)

This game doesn't even give a fraction of what it should give to 15 dollars. Get it free or don't get it at all.

31818020.review:
The game starts out like a really fun fast paced overly violent brawler type game. It is actually pretty fun for about the first 20 bosses. However after that the game gets really repetative and old fast. The game had some fun designs like a jetpack and some really fun weapons, but also made some very strange decisions as well. First and the thing that I disliked the most is how long some of the animations took to play. The game feels like it is designed to play fast and fun, but the flow is slowed way down for the kill animaitons. Second, there are many instant death traps. This means there are many times you could spend quite some time collecting coins you need to upgrade and buy more weapons, only to hit a spike while still at full health and instantly lose all the progress. This mechanic should not be in a game like this and made the game way less fun. Given everything about the game I feel the first part of the game is decently fun and could be a 7 or 8 out of ten, but after playing through the rest of the game I would have to say it is a 3/10.

TL;DR - The game starts out fun but gets old fast. Some strange game decisions make the game not as fun as it could be and it suffers because of these choices.

31544788.review:
When I began playing Hell Yeah! I was not sure if I could enjoy an action platformer that looks like Mario Bros. from the 1980s. It looks like an interactive cartoon movie that requires plenty of jumping and jumping skill are required to advance in this game. I do not play many action platformers. After playing the first zone for a little bit, I felt like I could slowly enjoy this game.

The basic theme of the game centers around Ash, the protagonist rabbit. He is the rabbit prince of hell who finds out that photos of him romancing with a rubber duck could be made public on the Hellternet, hell’s version of the internet. There are 100 monsters who saw the photos, leaving Ash with one choice: kill them all. The story takes place across 10 zones, but there are restricted parts of zones so that you can defeat a certain number of monsters so that doors can explode to give you access to more of the zone.

The zones are diverse enough and rendered in 2D environments. Zones include a casino, ruins, museum, volcano, a spaceship, etc. While there is a lot of jumping, you will face monsters very frequently. Monsters are of varying personalities. Some indicate that they are bored, some are hanging out with friends, and some are downright nasty. Each monster requires a strategy that is not straightforward. You must study the environment to understand the strategy that is required to defeat each monster. Many of these monsters are much larger than you are. You move around with a jetpack and drill to navigate spikes, walls, and various traps. The drill can be used to kill bugs, but they usually are no good against the largest monsters. For example, you must figure out how you can lure a monster to an area where slime can be dropped on him for the kill. The ten zones are graphically colorful and eye candy in 2D. It looks like a kiddie game with a sense of humor.

Defeating each monster usually leads to a minigame that must be completed properly to finish him/her off. Since there are way less minigames than monsters, they get repetitive. One minigame requires you to answer a trivia question and another requires you to powerlift a barbell so that your rabbit become large enough to kick the monster through a goal net, resulting in gibs that splash all over the screen.

When you are out of the game you can visit The Island, a private property of Ash that is used to enslave every monster you defeated. The benefit of every monster working on The Island is that they will give you gifts such as more health, more cash, and surprise items. They work in the harbor, the mines, the lab, and the manor. Some monsters will show unhappiness or anger, so they must be sent to the beach or the tower to take away their unhappiness or anger. You can zoom into the beach to see defeated monsters play a game of volleyball, which I found amusing.

As you explore the zones, there are plenty of coins and jewelry to collect and they are important for buying items from the stores. Items include upgrades for your firearms and various skins for customizing Ash. Skins include hats and bike outfits. Upgrades to the drill occur throughout the game, but they can only happen by progressing through the story. There is a lot of backtracking in the game. when you finish one of the later zones you will realize that you must return to zone 1 to defeat more monsters so that you can continue to open later zones in the end. This backtracking can feel like a little bit of a drag, but there is a teleport system to make your backtracking less tedious while you analyze the teleport system’s simple map.

The control scheme I used for this game was WASD for directions and the mouse for firing weapons. The jumping can be awkward and frustrating, especially when wall jumping. Other times a slight mistake in a jump can lead to instant death. I got used to the mouse/keyboard scheme with enough practice, but some may end up preferring to use a controller. The jumping gets more frustrating in parts of zones where you lose access to all your weapons and jetpack.

The weapons in the game are your basic ones such as a revolver, shotgun, grenades, rockets, flamethrower. There are a few unusual ones like a holy water. However, I did not find much variation in how much damage they do. The ammo does not actually run out since they only require recharging to fire again.

I found Hell Yeah! to be more fun than I thought it would be. Despite the sometimes-frustrating jumps, especially where Ash had no weapons or jetpack, I enjoyed the gameplay enough after adapting to the mouse/keyboard scheme. I also enjoyed the variety of settings in each zone, especially in the casino and in the spaceship while shooting asteroids, bugs, and monsters. Hell Yeah! is not a classic action platformer game, but it is a decent one by Sega and Arkedo Studio.

My Score: 7/10

Story about revenge and sawblade-drilling, multi-gun platform shooting.  Well, there are more genres like shooters, puzzles, button pressing finishes. reflex and timing sequences, and quizes. One of the sequences in each stage is called mission and is made of three challenges like: a race to reach the goal , a race to collect all the red rabbit tokens, perform stunts with the controller (which can be frustrating later on with multi-button presses and analog circle moves). 

The gameplay is forgiving most of the time if you take advangage of the health showers (blood showers) to regain health and  save and the game saves after successfully defeating a required enemy or reaching a certain point. There is also a creature management side game, which can produce new items.

The game control with the xbox controller is more loose than neccessary on the left analog stick, customizing to use the d-pad is not possible. While playing, I had to get used to stopping near hazards by jumping straight up to avoid  moving foward too far.

Music is not so memorable, except for a stage where there was a intentionally cheesy upbeat song

Cannot recommend this game except, if on sale.

30813580.review:
Devil In Hell!!! (God In Heaven didn't really seem appropriate here...) It's like Jazz Jackrabbit went EVIL! Dagn, Devs. What did you feel some sort of need to express you anger here? If so, keep doing it that way! That's gotta be the healthiest way to air out agression I've tried yet...
OK, in case you're confused, watch the trailer. Did that? Ok, now you probably have SOME idea what I'm talking about. Now let me just divulge here, not only does it FEEL good when you're the one cranking out the punishment on those, pic-stealing, no-bad (no-good doesn't really cut it here, does it?) laugh-at-the-dead-bunny-prince-of-hell-Demonfaces, you'll also have A LOT of rage to deal with when you FINALLY DO. This is ONE, ANNOYING, platformer-shooter-and-the-devil-knows-what-else! You'll get frustrated. Trust me. So when you finally DO get to duke out that over-the-top-excessively-brutal-style-punishment, it will feel SO, SO, OH SO GOOD!
Oh. Right. The game...
Well. It's over the top. It's a big barrel of laughs that (unfortunately) gets old sooner rather than later. (Once you've seen the first repetition Monster Death, leave the game for a while and come back at it when you've just about forgotten about it. It'll help with not getting bored with it. That's probably why they added the ah.... other thing in the game...)
The controls are VERY wonky to learn. Probably because once you FINALLY think you've got it down, you get to a part where you have to do it differently. All in all, I had a blast paying the game, I really did, but I got to feeling trapped more often than not, doing the same kind of thing over and over again, WAY too many times. The only real reason I think I said "damn it all" and finished it was that the levels and bonus stuff got SO hard it actually motivated me to get it the hell-bunny over with! That being said, I laughed my A## off almost every time I FINALLY killed one of them, (mostly because it got REAL hard in the end to keep your cool and adjust to whatever button combination or task you had to perform to get that AWESOME finishing move.)
I'm not gonna do numbers here, because for what the Devs were probably going for, The Controls, The Graphics, The... Everything about the Game is probably as close to perfect as they could get it. And it works. It's not gonna win GOTY but DAMNED it's a funny ride to go on once in a while, especially if you're feeling frustrated and want to take that out on some dumb looking monster with a finishing move you'll remember laughing at the most akward of times. If nothing else, people will ask you what you're laughinh about and you'll have the unenviable task of trying to explain the, um... - plot.
But all that aside, the game is gut-bustin' Fun and Old-School-Hard to Play. That by itself makes HY-WOTDR worthy of a Sequel and bigger and better things in the future, at least it does in my book.

29361858.review:
Hell, no!

I'm not the first reviewer to start the review off with that, but it's really true. This game is not very good at all. It's got a fun enough concept, and an interesting little section where you put the demons you've killed to work, but it utterly fails as a platformer:

- Floaty controls, no feeling of gravity.
- Able to slip off corner of platforms into instant death even though it look like you should be fine.
- Terrible controls where you can't select weapons on the keyboard without going to the weapons select screen and then waiting for a few seconds for it to dissapear, while the game continues in the background. You can use the mousewhell as well, but it cycles too fast to be precise and more often than not you end up on the wrong weapon doing that.
- 100 mini bosses (apparently), each with a checkpoint before the unskippable cutscene and dialog introducing the mini-boss so if you die (and you will a lot while you figure out the trick to each) you get to watch the cuscene again, and again...
- No weight to the weapons.
- Zoomed in very close and your weapons can't fire beyond the edge of the screen.
- Leaps of faith that can result in instant death.

It's a fun enough concept, and I actually like the mini-games after each boos that some others complain about, but steer well clear unless you get it for free. I gave it just over an hour and have had enough, so if I ever come back to it I may update this review if my mind changes, but I doubt it very much.

Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is.. acceptable but not much more. I finished the main game and its dlc missions in 11 hours so as far as value goes it is quite long with a fair amount of content! Although thats not to say you won't wish it didn't end sooner.

The problems come in the form of imprecise controls, a much too zoomed in field of view and what comes down to very shallow gameplay which doesnt hold your attention. For a platformer, the clunky controls are a far cry from the sharp dexterous command you have over your side-scrolling hero in a game like Super Meat Boy. The only charm this game has is its actual attempt to be charming as it lacks in almost every department except maybe art style and quirkiness.

I recieved this game for free as part of a SEGA promotion but that is no excuse for a loosely put together game. It is decent but I cannot recommend anyone to buy it. 5/10

26706050.review:
Hell Yeah! is a game with a lot of potential but leaves you with mixed feelings. The story is silly and filled with cartoonish gore. So not everyone will enjoy its weirdness. With its cartoonish direction, the graphics are great. They're bright and colorful. However, these colorful graphics are often too bright. Another problem with this is that everything (background and foreground) is bright and colorful making it difficult at times to distinguish what is dangerous and what is friendly (you may have to play it yourself to know what I mean...). And now Hell Yeah!'s biggest problem... platforming. It's really hard to defend an action platformer when platforming isn't tightly controlled. Controlling the jetpack buzzsaw isn't terrible. But it's slippery... It's floaty and too sensitive. This makes for some frustrating moments. And while there seem to be plenty of auto-save points, it still becomes annoying to replay sections over and over because of these slippery controls. On top of all that, the shooting is a bit slippery too... 

P.S. I received this game for free from a SEGA promotion so I can't complain but WOW! $15 is a bit steep for this one...

26610054.review:
"Alto juego, no se como no tuvo exito" dicen muchos cuando juegan un juego que es de culto, y casi siempre es verdad, hay muchos flor de juegasos que cuando te das cuenta lo conocen muy poco y en su mayoria de casos nunca tienen una secuela aunque se lo merescan de lo buen juego que son.

hasta que llega hell yeah...


Un juego que se va haciendo divertido, hasta que llegas a la mitad del juego y queres que termine..

El juego no seria "no" y mucho menos un "si" pero steam no deja elegir un termino intermedio, asi que se queda con un no, porque hasta regalado el juego se me fue dificil de digerir


Historia:
Somos ash, el principe conejo demonio esqueletico que gobierna el infierno hasta que un dia mientras se ducha con un patito, le sacan fotos y se dedica matar a 99 enemigos especiales durante todo el juego hacia el camino a los que tienen sus fotos.

Y hay un tipo que parece que es el que esta detras de todo esto que aparese al final del juego y ya esta.. el juego tiene 2 splot twist medio locos pero despues de eso la cinematica final del juego es de 10 segundos matando al jefe final y una frase estupida y no explican nada despues de eso, resumidamente: EL FINAL ES UNA MIERDAA

Gameplay:
Hell yeah es de plataformas con toquesitos de accion y metroidvania.
Lo admito, matar enemigos y luego tener que hacer un mini juego es divertido hasta que ya matas como a 71 enemigos y ya visto todo el juego porque las animaciones de "finish him" se repiten una y otra y otra vez, al igual que cuando derrotamos a los jefes especiales que al derrotarlo aparece una imagen estatica de una explocion nuclear. 4 veces...

Los escenarios casi siempre son insufribles, hay espinas que te hacen instant kill en casi todos lados.

Recuerdan que dije que es metroidvania? en este sentido me refiero que hay que matar X cantidad de enemigos para segir a otra parte, pero este juego es tan guiado que no hay mucha razon para volver a otros niveles y incluso es el metroidvania mas lineal que juge nunca, aunque si, hay misiones secundarias con retos en lugares donde antes no podias pasar pero.. meh.


Les dije que hay espinas que hacen instant kill?

Ademas los controles en pc, y un poco en general en el juego dejan algo que desear

El juego es muy facil, el juego se hace complicado porque esta mal hecho en muchas ocaciones y por ese mismo motivo el juego cuando perdes es mas bien culpa del juego el 60% de los casos y.. bueno, espinas que te hacen instant kill....

Graficos:
Bueno, es carton, pero se podia trabajar mucho mas en la animacion, y eso que me gustaron juegos como shank 1 y 2 que tambien son cartoon

Soundtrack:
Hay 3 tracks en el juego que estan buenos, el resto son bastante olvidables, y incluso la cancion de los creditos se repite como 10 veces (sin exajerar)


Veredicto final:
Leeyendo los pro tips del juego se dice que este juego empezo siendo un rpg tactico por turnos, si eso es verdad, se nota que este juego tuvo muchos problemas no solo economicos si no tambien de desiciones, y esto es lo que quedo, y a muchos les encanto, y no lo culpo, tal vez para algunos puede ser divertido y admito que hay chistes como [spoiler]Que el que te da las misiones secundarias es el protagonista del futuro que se termino el juego [/spoiler] pero en terminos mecanicos, el chiste del juego de matar y disfrutar de una animacion es un chiste que se repite una, y una, y otra, y otra vez.

Por menos de 5 o 3 dolares lo recomiendo, pero a mas de eso? no, difinitivamente no.

26239723.review:
The ground is constantly spouting fire. Red fire. Some spouting red fire hurts you, even though it's lower opacity, thinner, and generally less visually imposing. Bosses will roll over you and spawn huge walls of fire. But actually, the fire is purely cosmetic; it won't damage you. All this is in the first level, which is red in the foreground and red in the background.

I want to illustrate in the above point that the game's style COMPLETELY CONFLICTS with good game design. This happens everywhere. To have continuous, smooth animations, the game has to play in a weightless, floaty way--torpedoing rockets from your gun poof with a small purple cloud tweening and fading away (accompanied by a low-mixed sound effect), making it hard to tell if shots land. Your melee attack is signaled by a fade-in, fade-out blur SFX of white-blue against a usually gray-and-red-speckled sawblade. A pop-up appears to tell you that you can't saw into metal enemies, but a metallic sound effect doesn't play? Lol.

THE CAMERA IS SO ZOOMED IN with SUCH PLAIN, WIDE LEVEL DESIGN that you can snipe the first boss (and many other monsters) offscreen without even seeing their sprite. I assume that's to make the art look nice even at low resolution? It's pretty ridiculous.

This has all the elements of a good game but FEELS awful to play unless. Floaty, unsatisfying gamefeel and animations, unclear visual direction, low speed. It plays like a Newgrounds game. Trash.

Also, the humor was dated when it released and hasn't aged well. It's got this Happy Tree Friends forum member mix of lolsorandum and satire-less edge, like a newspaper headline's "THE PRINCE IS A PUSSY" in the opening cutscene to motivate the main character. Characters speak in tired, meme-like phrases and re-explain jokes immediately after they're delivered. The tutorializing character is an octopus Gir with a moustache and tophat.

In particular, Ash COMPLETELY breaks character to politely greet the first boss, and like... It happens over about 12 dialogue balloons. It's not delivered quickly enough to be irreverent and drags down the pace. The joke doesn't have the satisfaction of being humor built on characterization (at every other point, Ash is a rude loudmouth). Its humor is so bad you can write essays on how each joke doesn't quite work.

It's not comfortable being gory enough to delight in ultraviolence with its cartoony blood and slime splatters. Its uber-macho monster designs featuring overly-detailed lips, wrinkles, uncanny proportions, etc fail to be consistently creepy-cute. I don't know how it pleases anyone.

The SEGA costumes are cute, though. SUPER cute. Ever wanna play a game as Oppa-oppa riding one of the wheels from a pair of Jet Set Radio skates? Now you can.

26058828.review:
This is difficult to say, but I cannot recommend this game.

It looks good.  It plays well.  It's relatively fair in punishment for failure.

On the other hand, this is a repackaged Warioware.  There's a main game, then all of a sudden everything changes for no reason.  Mechanics are completely forgotten about, your character controls completely differently, and everything is suddenly based off of timed buton presses that you really can't prepare for.  Worse yet, sometimes pressing the buttons on screen leads to failure, and you eventually learn not to follow the instructions (looking at you chewing game that only requires two button presses).

I think the game is interesting, and it has the potential to be genuinely fun.  Unfortunately, it just never delivers.  You spend too much time in the main game to make this just a string of button press games, but the button mashing takes up too much time for the game to be a platformer broken up with mini-games.  


As a side note, whomever decided on the challenges which require doing tricks in the wheel is evil.  The button timing is less forgiving than a rhythm game, and success is generally had by button mashing.

25906355.review:
[h1]Bunny Hell[/h1]

I wasn't sure what I was getting into with this game. I took it for an action platforming game, which is only partially true. There is a lot going on here; shooting, exploration, mini-games, Quick Time Events ([b]QTE[/b] for the sake of this review), and probably the strangest collection mini-game I've ever encountered add up to a pretty solid title that is pretty good even if it isn't quite perfect.

The story is nonsense, I won't go into it too deeply but it is pretty ridiculous. The MacGuffin here is twofold; find embarrassing photographs, return a bunny ruler to his throne in Hell. The writing is highly amateur, and while I enjoyed some of the jokes I found myself speeding through a lot of the inane dialogue and bland humor.

As far as the game itself goes there is plenty to do and like, even if it's pretty uncomplicated. Levels are very linear, solving them really doesn't take a lot of thought or exploration. There are a LOT of bosses and mini-bosses throughout the game. After a while it gets daunting, mostly because of the QTEs that come with every single boss and mini-boss in the game. This wouldn't be as bad if the controls were better, but I will get to that in a moment. As the bunny you have a wide arsenal of upgradable weapons you will inevitably have to use, and while some of them were useful, none of them felt especially creative; guns, bigger guns, or automatic guns for example. You are able to fire these weapons except for some of the stages that take all of your weapons away or thrust you into completely different kinds of play, such as when you pilot various crafts throughout the game, man turrets, or are forced to navigate entirely on foot and unarmed. Checkpoints are plentiful, this game expects you to die and really doesn't punish too severely for it.

The controls felt loose and very slippery. I used a game pad for the most part, but even a keyboard and mouse couldn't help the sense that I was sliding a bit when I moved around. This is especially problematic on certain stages where instant death will happen if you can't pinpoint very precise jumps. There are bigger problems; every boss and mini-boss has a QTE, and there are a lot of them. The problem, is that some of these are not game pad friendly, one of them in particular didn't appear to work with the game pad at all, I had to resort to using the keyboard to complete these QTEs, and while that's not a big deal, it's worth noting that the controls here are just not the greatest. Another consideration are that the controls themselves are very awkward, especially with the game pad. I read a lot of comments in the discussions about this issue, many people suggesting that using the best way to play were the mouse and keyboard. If I could do this all over again for the first time I would have probably gone with their advice.

Visually the game is a bit of a throwback to 90s platforming games. Colors are bold and contrasting, giving the game a very vivid appearance. The areas and characters were well drawn, though some were also part of the humor, which means I didn't find all of them very funny or interesting, but there were a few that made me laugh. The screen can seem little busy at times, but beyond that the game looks really good. I wish more games were not afraid of this aesthetic; rich bold colors are a welcome change from a lot of the drab or subtle tones many games rely on now.

Music and sound effects are generic to good, some of the sounds seemed like stock sound effects. The music had all kinds of things happening that I found kind of interesting, and really amusing. The kiddie song on one of the stages was suitably saccharine, even hilariously twisted considering the stage and what was happening, while other songs were parodies, including one that sounded very curiously like the original Star Trek theme. The rest of the game is loaded with tracks that range from rock to thumping beats, and while they could be repetitive at times they were never really annoying. Actually the music overall was pretty good, and again some of it was a throwback to 90s platforming games I used to enjoy when I was a kid.

Overall a good game with a lot of things to see and do. Not much of a challenge, but not the easiest out there either. I hope they consider making a sequel, and if they do I hope they will try being a little more creative with their game design.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Big Arsenal of weapons
    [*]Catchy music
    [*]Visually well designed
    [*]Wide variety of level options
    [*]Mini-games and collectibles are unique and amusing
    [*]You get a lot for your money

[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Awkward game pad controls
    [*]QTEs get old
    [*]Some lame writing

[/list]

A fun game with a few weak points and some control issues. Recommended for platform fans, soft recommended for everyone else.

[h1]Hell Yeah is not perfect, but it did have me thinking "Hell Yeah".[/h1]

The dialogue is a bit cringeworthy, the sound assets are weird, the graphics are a bit hard on the eyes, and the gun controls are a bit wonky. Even so, this game has a lot of charm and even more great content. The whole gimmick of hunting down the 100 monsters and doing gorey Wario Ware-esque mini-games to finish them off is just great. Although the art is often a bit weird, the theming is actually quite good. The music is often so bad that it's good and you never feel like you're seeing the same scenery over and over again.

Overall, Hell Yeah is an easy recommendation for fans of oldschool platformers or oldschool run and gun games. I'd love to see a sequel.

25385858.review:
Not sure if it's worth the full price, but if you're really into platformers this is a fun little diversion. 

PROS:
* Mechanically sound, controls are fluid, at least with an XB controller. Haven't and don't intend to try with KB/M. Hitboxes are solid, almost everything is made obvious to the player, it functions as advertised. Mostly. Some of the jump physics are a little weird, but usually more in your favor than against.
* Joyfully nostalgic platforming. In many ways, I'm reminded of Jazz Jackrabbit, and if I didn't know any better, this game is paying some homage to it. The floaty jumping mechanics, aiming, variety of weapons, goofy humor, and the protagonist (anti-hero?) is, well, also a rabbit. 
* Weaves quick time events and platforming pretty seamlessly (though some of the animations could use to be shorter). The animations for beating said events are over-the-top and fun to watch, but mostly only for the first time.

NEUTRAL:
* Deaths are very forgiving. This is kinda cool since you'll likely Sonic-the-Hedgehog-style your way into some traps getting caught up in the action. Fortunately, the game gives you a neat function to zoom out (and simultaneously pause) with the right bumper on the controller, dunno what it is for KB/M, but it's a nice feature to let you formulate your next move.
* No variety in difficulty. It doesn't really need it though I guess, the difficulty is pretty balanced.
* Fourth-wall-breaking, light-hearted and occasionally raunchy humor. It mostly falls flat to me, but that's subjective so I can't knock it. It's like Disgaea level humor, if it were just one-liners and no voice acting.

CONS:
* As a result of the first two neutral points above, replay value is practically non-existent.
* So much happening on screen that we see two issues: first, it's often difficult to tell what's an enemy, a trap, or a piece of the foreground/background, unless you're frequently stopping to take in the scenery. Second, there are framerate stutters, but they're infrequent and don't really hinder gameplay *too* much unless you're making a precision jump at the time.


To conclude, might be worth picking up on sale for platforming nostalgia. It's not bad, but I don't think it's justified at full price.

25049278.review:
In the spirit of joining my fellow SEGA Nerds teammates, I decided to join the Annual SEGA Horror Fest with a review. While I may not be the most appropriate person to talk about Halloween, since we don’t celebrate it in my country, I tried to choose a title that’s more related to our “Día de los Muertos” (Day of the Dead), our national holiday that embraces our joy for life, the cult and nostalgia for our departed ones and also… to poke fun at death.

Precisely, that’s what Arkedo’s Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit does, poke fun at death, hell, and some other spooky things on the way. While French developers, Arkedo, might be long gone as a studio after a financial bankruptcy (should I dedicate a Mexican Día de los Muertos “Ofrenda” perhaps?), they certainly made games that were appreciated in a special way by some people (like Nervous Brickdown or Big Bang Mini for the Ninty DS).

A RESURRECTION FOR A PLATFORMER? 

For a start Hell Yeah! is a platformer, a genre that many thought dead but that’s been slowly coming back thanks to the necromancy of retro gaming. You control Ash, hell’s current underworld ruler, who is trying to hunt down some of his minions that are threatening him with releasing compromising photos to the public. As fun and weird as the plot sounds this translates into comedic and bizarre interruptions or mini games that appear as you progress though mazes in the underground, perhaps this is a double edge sword, cause while some of us SEGA fans might fall into the gag and follow by, some others might get desperate trying to know what’s going on, because the game is not very intuitive in explaining these “on the go” mechanics. For example, some bosses require to aim and shoot as a mini game, but some people might not get how to do it, cause the game does not do a very good job on explaining so or that it is part of a gag.

For most, the game has a lot of fun to offer, but also requires to master some skill, since the controls require you to switch between sticks to aim for certain parts or to zoom out the screen to aim and hit some enemies.

SOMETHING FOR THE SEGA FANS

The game has a lot of fanservice for the average SEGA fans. As you progress in the game you unlock SEGA Character themed add-ons like JSR or Shinobi hats or items, you can also equip your attacking wheel with more weapons or features. There are also other fun hubs like your own island were you send your defeated enemies and punish them as it must due!

A KILLER OST AND VISUALS TO DIE FOR

There are 2 things that outstand in this game, its vector based visuals & character designs and its amazing OST. The vector artwork shines so well in this game and allows you to enjoy the aesthetics no matter the resolution, specially in PC, Arkedo did a great job. The OST is something to enjoy on its own, even if you don’t buy the game you can still download this awesome score, it has something for almost everyone, from lullabies to hardcore punk, and every tune fits perfectly in the game.

SUMMARY

This game is fun and enjoyable, but might not be appropriate for the narrow minded player. While its true that pretty visuals and a good OST are not all in a game, the title lacks of some areas to be polished like a more polished gameplay and controls.

Pros:

+ Amazing visuals and OST
+ Fanservice for the SEGA fans
+ Fun times and fart-type jokes

Cons:

– Not for everyone
– Requires control skill
– Lacks of explanation for some mechanics

24921679.review:
Hell Yeah! is a holy mess. There's good ideas, but their burried in clunky controls and hit detection, repetitiveness, and overall a feeling of "too much". Too much redundent weapons, too much forced bargin bin mini games, too much juvenile humor, too much unskippable cutscenes and shoddy dialogue, too much color and objects bursting on the screen at all times making it hard to see. Despite all this, the pace is unbearably slow.

The execution lets down any potential the game really had. There's a separate side game called The Island, where you have defeated enemies work for you for cash, health, or items, but the rewards are minor and uninteresting, and the system itself is a boring distraction.

Hell Yeah! shoots for the stars and misses all 1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 of them.

[h1][u]Score: 6/10[/u][/h1]

[b][u]Summary[/u][/b]
Hell Yeah! Which basically sums things up. The rabbit prince of hell is caught with his rubber ducky. Photos are taken. You must kill and traverse to get revenge and same said photos.

[b][u]Positive[/u][/b]

+ Weapons are fun.
+ Custom Skins are goofy and a fantastic addition.
+ Oozing with graphic style.

[b][u]Negative[/u][/b]
- Controls are mostly solid, but you slide often which can easily kill you.
- The novelty of the mini games and humor wear off.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is a style over substance game with tons of Warioware moments that feel good. You have to be in the mood for a just plain stupid type of fun game to play it.

[b][u]Value[/u][/b]
I'd say $3.75 or so.

A simple, casual platformer with clean controls, good humor, but little difficulty and some minor level design problems. Although the level design looks like a Metroidvania game, this is more of a mask as there are almost no collectibles and you don't gain any new abilities that change access in the old levels (aside from a generic progression system of "upgraded drill"). 

PROS:
-Great art / animations
-Soundtrack was amusing 
-Locations were varied and entertaining
-Controls are clean
-3 different "forms" throughout the game but controls are consistently good for them all.

NETURALS:
-Ship/Submarine mode was a bit shallow. Mainly just mazes.
-"The Island" seems pointless. Throughout my playthrough I was awarded $100 1 time. Not sure if I should have checked it more or not but I don't see the point.

CONS:
-Cannot skip dialogue scenes (not that many but still).
-"Missions" are very poorly designed. Many of them say to "race to the goal" but there are no markers or identifiers as to where the goal is!
-VERY easy.
-Although the game looks like a Metroidvania game, it has very few collectibles (1 per game zone, like 8 or 9 total) and the levels simply "unlock" as you progress. There is no use of newly found abilities (there are none) to access old areas aside from a "drill upgrade" that lets you go through stronger colored rock. Very generic progression in the level design masked as Metroidvania.

23755625.review:
Divertidisimo juego de plataformas en el que la absurda trama sirve de puente para tener que eliminar a 100 enemigos con unos ataques finales de lo más absurdos pero divertidos y que se activan a traves de diferentes minijuegos. 

La verdad es que no esperaba que fuese tan divertido y currado así que me ha sorprendido para bien. Gráficamente tiene un bonito estilo 2D muy cuidado, con diferentes estéticas bien marcadas y personajes muy bien animados, muy fluido todo. Es muy agaradable a la vista vaya.

En cuanto al gameplay, los controles son geniales, responden super bien y rápido. El control es sencillo pero efectivo y tienes muchas armas diferentes a parte de la sierra principal. Además el personaje también es personalizable y hay desbloqueables tanto de aspecto como de armas y objetos.

Tiene también misiones secundarias y algun modo de juego extra aunque lo más destacable es la campaña, el resto son añadidos que están bien para mirar de vez en cuando como el modo isla. Es más una gracia que otra cosa xD.

El juego en general no es muy difícil, las plataformas no son la principal dificultad en este caso, si no los enemigos y averiguar como matar a cada uno de los objetivos ya que cuando se va avanzando ya no será tan facil con algunos como usar tus armas. Tiene bastantes cosas orginales en su desarrollo y formas de matarlos, y sobretodo mucho humor genial.

Como negativo solo le veo que peca de repetitivo, siempre se hace lo mismo y los minijuegos para matar a los enemigos se acaban repitiendo, algunas variaciones en algunos pero se repiten. El desarrollo siempre es igual pero los diferentes lugares y algunas cosas que van añadiendo como el magnetismo o un lugar super yupi (los que hayais jugado ya lo sabeis... y que música más pegadiza!!!), hace que haya alguna variación al avanzar.

De duración está bastante bien y cumple, y no se alarga más de la cuenta como suele pasar en estos juegos. Si quieres hacerlo todo si que puede alargarse un rato más pero no tiene tanto tampoco como para hacerse demasiado más largo.

Sonido genial y música chula con tema pegadizo incluido xD. En resumen, juego muy recomendado a los amantes de los plataforma o este tipo de juego y que os apetezca algo de humor desenfadado, sin mucha historia (que podría haber tenido algo más la verdad). Risas aseguradas.  ¿Y que hay mejor que ir por el infierno con el conejo suelto? ... si, suena fatal xD.

23562667.review:
If you like games with fluid controls, the ability to skip cutscenes, non-cheap deaths and interesting character interaction, you definitely are playing the wrong damn game if you pick this horrible title up. 

It's trying to be a 2-D Metroidvania style platformer with areas you can go back to eventually, and lots of random abilities to let you go wherever you want, but the controls are god awful. Either you use a pair of sticks (Yes BOTH sticks) to move yourself (The Left Stick) and aim your guns (The Right Stick) which means you'll often be either not moving to avoid hits, or you'll be moving and not firing, or you use the keyboard and mouse to move/attack, which I haven't tried yet but it sounds about as logical as a rabbit ruling hell and losing his seat of power to bathing with a rubber duck.

The opening cutscene doesn't actually run properly, with audio issues galore and sounding like the teacher from the Charlie Brown movies trying to tell a story, while the visuals are static and chopping at best. My machine must not exceed the necessary minimums enough, but even then, there's no reason for it to have no way to go below 1024 x 720 while playing. And there are monsters who can kill you almost instantly, and you have to muddle through their taunting dialouge over and over again. Speaking of which, the respawn time for the monsters is about as long as it takes for them to disappear from the screen's view, so be prepared to kill the same three guys over and over again as you move four inches forward.

Not only are the controls pretty bad for the gunplay, but there are sections that require you to use your circular blade to dig through the ground. THis would be fine if it weren't finicky at best, holding down the right trigger while shifting the stick around to dig can sometimes leave you in stupid positions or not breaking the blocks you want to, but then we get to the jumping. The jump button is a simple press/hold of A, but the height you'll hit is RANDOM. Sometimes you go high, sometimes you go low. BUt often times, you just go straight into spikes, into an enemy you don't want to touch, or under a falling block that kills you. Oh, and Spikes are instant death. For no reason other than to screw you over.

All in all, I didn't pay anything for this game, and I want my money back. Don't waste your time on this steaming turd. Sega, you can and should have done better.

23301701.review:
I'm not going to beat around the bush here. This game is not good, and it is quite the example of false advertising. In fact, I'd rather go to Hell than be forced to play this game again. 

This game appears to be targeted to the "I'm 14, I play Five Nights at Freddy's and I'm so edgy and random lolz rawr XD" crowd. Everything revolves around this motif. The protagonist is a cartoon skeleton rabbit that shoots his way through a Hell, flled with more cartoon animals. The artwork looks like doodles in a notebook, and the sound effects and music do not particularly fit with the theme and the concept. Listening to "The Crunge" or "D'yer Mak'er" on repeat for a few hours is a far more fitting soundtrack. At least the memebers of Led Zeppelin realized how ridculous these songs are, which maes them enjoyable. The game developers, however, lacked this self awareness. The unskippable and repititive dialogue (more on that in a moment) is filled with bad one liners and attempt to be funny. You know when an adult tries to be relatable and cool? This game does exactly that. In fact, I'm surprised that Hillary Clinton hasn't used it as part of her strategy to reach out to millenials (this is not a political post please don't attack me Valve mods).

The actual gameplay itself is marred by several serious flaws. The controls are incredibly awkward, and they somehow feel both stiff and slippery. It feels like someone coated the character in cold butter and threw him onto an ice skating rink. I know that WASD is not great for platformers, but it still is so strange. The rabbit has trouble dodging objects in mid air, which is something you need to be able to do well in order to advance in this game. He also seems to slide after you let go of the movement keys, which has gotten me killeed multiple times. 

I tried using a controller, as the game promised controller support, but guess what? IT DIDN"T WORK. I even tried it with multiple controllers, so I am sure it is not a problem on my end. With a controller, I couldn't jump or shoot. These are the two things you need to be able to do in order to play the game. I tried remapping the buttons in the options, but it wouldn't let me. This false advertising irritates me, and I'm suprised at how many games keep doing it.

Speaking of options, the option menu is absolutely pitiful. There are two options from what I remember. These are very basic keyboard remapping (no controller for you, peasants) and the option to change the sound from stereo to mono. That's right, no opton for changing the graphics settings. The game runs at a constant 720p, and upscales to your resolution. It already looks strangely upscaled on my 1080p screen, so I'd hate to see it on a 1440p or 4K monitor.

The action in the game is very mediocre. You get to choose between a variety of weapons, such as a sawblade, a rocket launcher, grenades, and assault rifle, etc.. The only problem is, however, the game restricts weapons to specific enemies. This only raises the question: WHY EVEN HAVE WEAPON VARIETY IN THE FIRST PLACE?! It's a pitiful attempt at diversity and longevity that I cannot appreciate. The whole gimmick with the bosses is that once you defeat them, you get to play a minigame to watch a gory death animation. These come in two varieties. You get to mash a button, you you get to hit a button at just the right time. These animations are reallly just glorified quick-time events. The horse is dead far before this game stops beating it.

These issues are made even worse with the fact that there is no post hit invincibility. If this was just restricted to a certain game mode, I'd be fine with that. But, ths lack of protection makes the bad controls even worse. You can be bounced all around the map and quickly go from 250 to 0 in a matter of seconds. It is downright infuriating how cheap this game can be because of it.

The godawful cutscenes are another issue. I mentioned that they were repetitive and unskippable. I stopped paying attention because every dialogue feels the same. Ash is a teenage punk, and talks back to authority figure because he is so edgy. It gets old quick. Also, you can't skip them. You just have to mash the mouse in order to go through as quickly as possible. There isn't even voice acting. IT's just reading. I don't mind reading, but if I wanted to read, I would grab a book. Also if you die during a boss fight, which you most certainly will beause if the garbage controls. you will often be forced to go through the dialogue you just read again. This is so annoying, and I hate it when developers don't fix this issue. No one wants to read your stupid text bubbles again.

Overall, the game tries to be something that it's not. It tires to be a cool, edgy game with a unique feeling and concept, but it falls flat on its face with boorish storytelling and incompetent implementation. In fact, it eerily reminds me of Shadow The Hedghog. Both games star male animal protagonists that shoot and kill their way through dark, gritty, yet cartoony settings. They each have notoriously bad controls and serious game design issues. To give it that extra touch of cringe, both were published by none other than SEGA. You'd they they'd learn after their first try at such a game. Overall, I give it a 4/10. Maybe I'm just being too critical. After all, it is only a SEGA game that I got for free.

However, if you are one of those 14 year olds I was talking about...

10/10 edgiest game I've ever played

CRAWLING IN MY SKIN

23295510.review:
Hell Yeah! is... complicated. There's a large cast of enemies with unique (often disturbing) designs, each with their own little tidbits about them and name, there's very few repeats and recolors amongst them. The game itself is energetic, chaotic, and every stage will usually add something new to play with. On top of that the game plays well. The issue is that there's a lot of components in place that MAKE a great game it's just the execution ultimately makes Hell Yeah! mediocre, but still memorable enough to garner some sort of affinity - either postive or negative.

So let's start with the design. Hell Yeah!'s plot is essentially "compromising photos get out that undercut the ruthless and cruel nature of the Prince of Hell, Ash (which is you), 100 monsters saw it so 100 monsters (and the so-and-so who took those pictures) have to die, go get 'em tiger." As soon as you get into it, you'll notice how brightly colored and animated literally everything is. It's VERY difficult to pay attention to everything and Ash moves pretty quickly meaning you'll likely run into things. As nice as all the animated things are, the fact that the background is as alive as it is most of the time, it'll be difficult to spot the various traps and shots going your way. Meaning you'll die, a lot.

Ash attacks mostly through use of his giant saw-wheel-jetpack which can drill and shoot. You won't really be drilling much unless to kill simple enemies who get too close and to drill through certain rock formations. As soon as you hit zone 2, drilling enemies is overall a bad idea and is replaced by shooting them. Soon after that you realize that with the proper upgrades, you can have your guns drill much more effeciently for you (hint: buy the shotgun and missile upgrades, you'll rarely need the gun later in the game) meaning that drilling isn't that great. Same thing for a dash upgrade which requires you to stand completely still to charge before going forward a rather pitiful distance. Great for drilling certain structures but ultimately very niche and you won't be using it much because - again - missiles and missile type weapons are better for drilling. Finally, certain enemies can only be shot and killed from certain angles so you might be jumping and shooting a lot, which is hard given that you have to aim with the right stick (if you used a controller like I did, as the game recommends) and jump with the A button. Which is really awkward. Meaning you'll die, a lot.

Finally, the game is cluttered with somewhat invisible checkpoints at moments where the game decides it's important to save your progress. If you die, you lose everything you got from before you activated that checkpoint. Typically there's a checkpoint after killing one of the many monsters and through important stretches. But these are numerous enough to be useless at certain points and agrivating when they don't come up after particularly difficult stretches of a level (I'm looking at you underwater zone 3). So if you go through a long maze-like area, grab a lot of money which you need for upgrades and better weaponry, and then get killed by a boss or by the level itself and have to grab it again. Even better, the game will record how much health you had at the checkpoint, meaning that you can respawn in a difficult area only to be severely handicapped until you find a health station somewhere, often much too far away. As if to remedy this there are items you can purchase that will temporarily aid you and boost your survivability until death but these are even RARER so they're never really useful even when you find one of the few shops. Killing a monster also requires beating a short mini-game each and every time, some are difficult some aren't, and they all increase in difficulty as time goes on. There's enough variation that they aren't annoying features, but what is an annoying feature is that failing them recovers some of the monster's HP and takes away a scaled chunk of yours, depending on how far into the game you are. Meaning that you'll die- you catch my point yet?

Most of this review has been negative, but I don't want to take away the fact that I am recommending this game because despite these flaws it's still very entertaining and unique. Well, as long as you can tolerate the emo cute theme, I liked it so I was fine with it. There's a lot in here that makes it feel bloated, but still not to the point that undermines what this game does effectively. Exploration is encouraged and fun, yet restricted from a linear path that you HAVE to take. There's a little management game that you can play with defeated monsters in the background, but the rewards are pretty much worthless and there's very little interactive elements to it. Weapons are unique with their own abilities, but are typically beaten out by its upgrade or weapons you can buy from the shop. Levels and stages are unique so you can't guess what'll come next, but there's no real feeling of progression as every level is disconected. Defeating monsters is cathartic and a large majority of them are absolutely horrifying and wonderful, you can see the love put into them, but the minigames make some more annoying than difficult and pad out every fight.

Really every thing this game does right is hindered by another element. But it still tried to do these things and they almost worked, it's really really close. To me that's what matters and that's why I recommend it. Though more around the $10 mark than full price.

23246575.review:
I actually don't know how I got this game, it just kind of appeared in my library one day and probably piggy-backed on another purchase like an internal parasite you pick up after an international vacation.

First off, this game thinks that this game is ****-ing hilarious.  It tries to tell a lot of jokes, and will often spend time relishing in it's own punch lines, but for something that wants to be edgy and over-the-top I mostly just found it really boring.  The humor is akin to a second-rate Saturday morning cartoon.  If that's your thing, more power to you.

For me it was just a mediocre platformer that never really got me excited. It's basically a Metroid-vania game where all the upgrades systems feel roughly identical and neither the platforming or the combat get fleshed out enough to allow for skillful play.  Most of the deaths I got felt very cheap due to the camera being too zoomed in on the character (environmental awareness is crucial for a good platformer).  It's very frustrating to lose a lot of your health to some cheap enemy placement and have to backtrack past your last checkpoint to an earlier health station.  Bleh!

They also include some Wario-ware style mini-games when finishing a boss and the game just doesn't have the comedic timing or punch to make those as spectacular as the developers probably intended.  Mostly it just adds to the frustration when you lose your last bit of health to their "LULZ, SO RANDOM" style finishers and have to restart the same friggin' checkpoint again.

Not technically poor or especially bad, just doesn't stand out as a platformer you should be spending your money on.

23217414.review:
This game is a 2D platformer about a devil rabbit named Ash, who is literally the prince of Hell. I got for free back in February and haven't bothered playing it for a while, but I just started playing now and it's awesome!

So, the story is that Ash's nudes get leaked online. No, i'm being serious. The photos already have 100 views, so Ash decides to go to kill all 100 Monsters that may or may not have viewed them.

The controls are very simple, it's a Metroidvania style thing. At the start of the game, you get a cool saw-jetpack thingy and are able to jump higher and drill through walls and kill enemies. You'll eventually get cool stuff like guns and missiles! I prefer you use a controller, preferrably the Xbox One controller, because it's a bit better than using a keyboard and mouse.

You kill a monster by, yes, depleting it's energy. When you deplete the bar, you enter a Wario-Ware style minigame that's really fun to play. You can fail sometimes, y'now. Your health is in the form of energy. You can get it by replenishing it at ''blood stations'' or killing enemies. Then, the cool part comes. You can send them to ''the Island'', where the Monsters you defeated can work labour for you and give you extra blood, money and gear in the main game/

I'm only on Zone 3 in the game so far, but it's shaping up to be a very fun platformer.

23105418.review:
Great, irreverant fun. Not very difficult, but still challenging enough to be interesting.

Pros:
-Good writing with lots of meta humor that really works, as well as just lots of silliness in general. Quite charming!
-Graphics are charming and enjoyable
-Good controls
-Satisfying and very varied finishers for bosses and sub-bosses 
-Sega references galore, and THEY USE THE 1991-1995 SEGA CHORUS FROM CLASSIC SONIC GAMES 
-Music is decent
-You can put your victims to work on a... resort island in hell. You become their HR manager, essentially, and keeping them happy and productive nets you food (health items), money, bonuses and more. It's kinda its own game within the game and I can see people easily getting attached to that half. 

Cons:
-Not a problem for myself, but some people may be turned off by the crude humor (I think there is a menstruation joke, but I wasn't quite sure. The nurse character? Anyone else?)
-Level layouts sometimes seem haphazard and not really planned. (Not a major issue for me, and I'm about an hour in at this point)

23075568.review:
I have played this game before on the PS3 when i got at as a free game via Playstation Plus. I enjoyed my time immensly back then and felt like diving in again in this colorfull Metroidvania adventure about the bunny Prince of Hell Ash and his quest to destroy 100 monsters who saw emberassing photos of him. The plot is so unbelieveably simple and doesn't take itself seriously at all, which adds to the visuals aswell.

This time i also enjoyed my time with Hell Yeah, but not quite as much as when i used to back then 4 years ago when the game first released. The gameplay is smooth as butter, the gunplay is great and it feels great to explore the lands and be on the hunt for the next monster. Also the soundtrack is still really great, fits the levels fantastically and that one song in the Cute World is still stuck in my head because how catchy (yes i know it's cheesy as hell) it is.

However, there were two things that bugged me a little while playing the game and made me notice that the game feels a bit 'old' even if it just came out not to long ago. First of were the graphics, were it felt a bit...odd to me. Some of the animations are a bit too cheap, downright 2 frames animations and looked quite laughable at times (especially the Guitar killing thing where the hands stretch the Monster, that looked really awful). Otherwise you have some nicely drawn, whacky cartoony characters which are with a few exception all pretty well drawn. I generally like Ash's design alot.

Speaking off the finishers, these happen every time you kill one of the 100 Monsters you need to hunt down. Allthough there are many finishers with unique animations and how you perform them, they repeat themselfs  often and they get old rather quickly, with no option to skip. This can be pretty tiresome watching the same thing over and over again with no chance whatsoever. Most of these finishers are references to some pop culture media, which brings me to my next big point, the humor.

The humor is a mix of basic "lol gory and butts and cursing" and pop culture references. It really is nothing big, and even though it made me laugh alot back in the day, it didn't even really made me chuckle once on my new playthrough. It's just a shame because i thought the games humor would hold up a bit better after just 4 years of age. Luckily the gameplay and overworld art make up for it.

Still, i find Hell Yeah! a pleasurable experience and find it sad that the developers, Akedo Studio, disbanded in 2013, which also kills the hope for a sequel.

As for a recommendation, the game is pretty short and rather easy. After completion there is not much to do really, the unlockables are not worth it, the missions are lame and "The Island" is trash. So yeah, pick it up when it's on sale, for 5-7 bucks you will enjoy this little rabbit adventure.

23048043.review:
[b]A cartoony metroidvania-esque game.[/b]
Its gameplay consists of the typical shootyshoot and platforming like many other metroidvania titles have although it's incredibly underwhelming in the metroidvania area since there is very little reason to go back to anything aside from the few points when you have to near the end of the game. There are some cosmetic gifts you can try to find and some simple side missions but they're not very rewarding themselves.

Playing with both a KB+M and a controller are both doable. During some segments though it's far more ideal to use the mouse for the faster aiming since for some reason using the right analog stick for these particular sections is incredibly slow whilst the mouse is as fast as you move it.

This game likes to emphasize about its loads of violence & gore but it's hard to take seriously since the entire game's animations look like something I'd see in a mobile game. With its groan-inducing humor and cartoony artstyle though I guess it shouldn't entirely be taken so.

The main goal throughout the game is just to platform your way through extremely standard maps to find and kill special monsters so you can unlock doors where you're to platform and kill more monsters so you can unlock more doors to do the same thing and eventually fight a boss, which itself is a part of the special monster pool. The special monsters are basically the keys to unlock doors when they're dead and for most of them it's an incredibly tedious process since the method for taking them down are usually either shoot them down or grind them down with your sawblade. Afterwards, as their HP reaches 0, you have to go through this Warioware-like minigame each time. If you fail the minigame you take loads of damage and they remain alive so you'd have to hit 'em a small bit [i]again[/i] to get their HP down enough and do the minigame [i]again[/i] where upon actual victory, you'll be treated to an unskippable slideshow-esque Adobe-Flash-like cutscene of a kill. Because there are loads of these special monsters in the game you'll encounter the same minigame and cutscene again and again, so even if you're a fan of the eye-rolling humor in the game they'll lose their appeal. As I got bored of seeing the minigame's reused cutscenes I tried alt+tabbing to another window for a bit and apparently it pauses the entire game sort of so the cutscene itself would just hang there until I went back to the game where it'd finally continue the little slideshow.
While much of these monsters are tedious to kill there are quite a few that get pretty clever in terms of finding the method of killing special monsters but these mostly appear at the later half of the game. At these times the game turns into a puzzle platformer sort of.

Nearly all weapons have unlimited ammo as they constantly recharge themselves. I never found myself using all of them since I didn't particularly need more than but a few. 
If you're using a controller, trying to use the sawblade and a gun can get confusing. By default you press RT to drill with the sawblade but to shoot your guns you have to aim with the right analog stick and then press RT. I found myself drilling accidentally when I should shoot too many times.
For some wad of a reason anything that's even mostly off-screen is invincible. You can shoot in their direction but if you can't see them you can't hurt them no matter how big of a target they are. This becomes a serious problem against enemies that require you to move a lot to evade anything that'd hurt you. It's as if your fired projectiles disappear from the game as soon as they leave the screen.

Checkpoints aren't the best and are made a little worse plenty of times when they're right before a cutscene of sorts where characters speak. Each time you die at these times you'll have to go through the cutscene over and over again. You can't skip these dialogue things entirely so all you can do is mash NEXT until it's all over each time in case you'd rather not go through all that again, and even that's still slow.

It's a simple game overall with humor for the lowest common denominator but I definitely don't think it's $15 worth for little content.

22973643.review:
[h1]In few short words[/h1]
Hell Yeah! is a 2D platformer, like no others, with a huge amount of humor and elements that bring quite some addiction. It's totally a must for everyone that likes platformers, wants to get some laughs or maybe even got bored by other more 'common' platformers.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay overall is fun and addicting, besides the main-game, you also have few "mini-games" when you kill bosses, which are very entertaining.
The game can be challenging sometimes, not too much, not too less. 
You have multiple weapons to choose from, and a set of abilities.

Who wouldn't like playing as a psychopathic mad rabbit with an arsenal of tools designed for killing?

[b]Soundtrack[/b]
While it might not join my Top 5 OSTs, it sure is very nice and fits the game perfectly, you can hear in the music that the artists put quite some effort in making it.

[i]You're a fancy bunny, together, we're happy...[/i]

[b]Hidden stuff and achievements[/b]
I want to say that this game has dozens and dozens of easter eggs, some are obvious, some are less obvious, and the developers implemented them in the funniest ways possible.

Achievements - Some of you might like collecting achievements and to get them until the very end.
In this game, achievements are relatively easy to get, personally, the most time consuming one took me around 2 hours of constantly pressing the bloody 'E' key trying to get the highest prize on slots.

'Hunting' achievements in this game was a very fun and joyful ride for me, and i hope it will be for you too.

[b]Bottom Line[/b]
I personally consider it does have plenty of replayability.

[i]Final Scores[/i]
Gameplay 95/100 
Story 100/100
Soundtrack 85/100 (It was great, but wasn't exactly my style)

22969107.review:
I've never been a big fan of platformers or this genre Steam calls "Metroidvania", so I wasn't particularily interested in playing this game, but since I got it free with a Sega bundle here on Steam back in February 2016, I figured I give it a try. I've played Metroid on the NES as a reference.

This stylish game has an amusing story about the prince of hell (who is a rabbit), who sets out to restore his dignity by killing 100 monsters after photos of him with a rubber duck in a bathtub were affecting his street cred.

The gameplay consists of running around a large (ish) map, collecting money and killing weak enemies while searching for the bosses that are your targets. You will often kill them in unique ways that feature a small mini game event. Once the enemies are killed, you can order then to do things for you in a seperate mini game such as collect coins or treasures.You then proceed through the door that only opens based on your current boss kill count and then continue the process until you reach the stage boss. Sometimes you come across a store where you can buy customization skins for your character, or new weapon and health upgrades.

There are not a lot of mobs to kill in the first couple chapters, there are a lot of annoying instant kill hazards, (though the game seems to have unlimited lives) and a lot of bosses to fight...but the whole process just feels like a chore to me.

The game ran flawlessly on the desktop pc used at the time which was a Windows 7 64 bit Core2Duo 1.8 Ghz, with a Geforce GT 430 1024 MB.

I found the overall presentation and style of the game to be very good with decent music and sound effects, but I did not find the gameplay fun at any point during my 3 hours of playtime, and that is what matters the most.

As I mentioned, I've never been a fan of the genre, but I personally found this game to be rather boring and I figured I would offer my opinion of my experience.

I certainly don't feel this game is worth the full price of $16.99 CDN, so unless you're a huge fan of this genre, I would avoid this game.

There are better games to spend your time on.

22737312.review:
The prince of hell (a skeleton rabbit with a cape) got photographed together with his rubber duck and is lampooned on the internet for it. The only reasonable reaction — of course — is to kill everyone who has seen those embarrassing pictures.
Developer Arkedo sets Hell Yeah's morbid humourous tone from the very start of the game. What follows is a surprisingly good 2D platformer.

On his journey to kill every single one of the 100 monsters fallen in disgrace, our hero rabbit visits various areas of hell, ranging from a casino to space. The game is packed with comic like brutality; exploding enemies, blood fountains and grotesque finishing moves.
On first sight, Hell Yeah seems like one of those gag games, that aim to be taken with a pinch of salt and don't really try to be good games at core. I'm talking about the likes of Brütal Legend or Goat Simulator; games that wouldn't be enjoyable, if their mechanics were stripped off their context. But after finishing Hell Yeah, I feel like I should give up on that prejudice towards gag games.

Hell Yeah takes typical platformer mechanics, like wall jumps, moving platforms and Donkey Kong Countryesque cannons, and combines them with guns, which can aim in 360 degrees, and a buzz saw. That core mechanic itself is functional — precise jumps were a bit tricky though, because there's next to no acceleration and only one movement speed (the directional input is binary and there is no run button).

Steady variety is what makes the game fun in the end. You can play on gambling machines in the casino. There's a part where you operate a submarine and you can shoot rainbows, that bounce off of walls, somewhere else.
Finishing moves are a source of variety too. The monsters don't have individual moves, but more than 25 different finishers are included in the game. They are occasionally really creative and particularly show of the games polished visuals. All of them start with a short quick-time-event or mini game, making them clearly more interesting than most games finishing moves, but bottom line, they still get old after you see the same animation the third time.

After finishing the game, I was positively surprised how much bang I got for the time invested. Every mechanic and idea is used for a short amount of time and then dropped for something entirely new. Take the rainbow gun I mentioned earlier. You get the gun play three or four different situations with it — which all require the gimmick, that shots bounce off walls — and then you never see it again.
On the other hand, the short innovation cycle leaves no room for any of the mechanics to grow complex, which again, fits the far from serious visual and narrative style of Hell Yeah.
It's a cool game. It cracks the jokes, shows off some crazy ideas and ends before it gets repetitiv. Play this with a friend and a few bottles of beer and I bet you have on or two great evenings.

Read more of my reviews at:
theguygaming.com

In Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit you play as the prince of hell, who was photographed secretly by paparazzi while bathing, now you go on a quest to find all 100 monsters in hell who have seen your nudes and exact revenge.  Gameplay wise I feel like it sits in a place in between platformer and twin stick shooter.

 There are a variety of weapons and tools to use in your quest including but not limited to, Rocket launchers, mini guns, grenade launchers, giant buzsaws, shotguns, and lazers. After defeating each monster to finish it off you are brought into a variety of WarioWare type minigames to get that final hit. if you fail the boss heals a little and you have to do it again. While not complex the finishers were pretty fun, in my opinion.  

The game has a lot of stuff in it to do, you've got customizations to collect, weapons to purchase, and even an island where you keep your monster friends who do jobs for you (slave labor). There are even side missions you can complete for extra rewards. While the game is not very long if oyu rush through it, it can be quite substantial if you try to collect everything and 100 percent it. 

I recommend Hell Yea! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit to fans of platformers, adventure games, sidescroling shooters, and anyone who just likes and indie game with cheesy comedy.

22337807.review:
Would I recommend this game?  No.  Not really.  Its a fun little game with a lot of personallity, but from my own experience, the game is frustrating in the controls department.  This game is not good for a platformer, which you have to do a lot as you get farther into it.  The controls just aren't made for platforming, its really slippery, not to mention the jumping isn't even jumping.  Its hard for me to describe.  The "jump" is this weird jetpack-like thing, except you go from 0 to 60 in less then a second, and is very hard to be percise with.  The combat is very...  Okay, nothing revolutionary, but not bad at all.

Thats just when you get you're primary way of dealing with enemies.  There is a level which is mostly on foot, during which you rarely have any weapons to deal with threats.  You have a double jump and a wall jump while on foot.  Double jump, good, wall jump, bad.  Wall jumping in a game like Megaman X (a very good SNES game) is good.  However the wall jumping in this game is automatic as long as you hold the jump button against a wall.  It makes the whole thing frustrating.  I just wanted to rapidly mash the jump button like in Megaman X.

So, gameplay-wise I think it works decently, just lackluster and frustrating from time to time.  The biggest issue I've had with this game is crashes.  Everytime I play this game it crashes.  Its happens when I enter or exit boss doors, and when I enter new levels.  Thats the only bug I've encountered during my time with this game.  Overall, its a decent game, but with the constant crashes I cannot recommend it.

Edit: Added the second paragraph about the on foot controls.
