22287971.review:
Ha ha, [b]Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit[/b] is a zany comedy action-platformer where you go on a bloody rampage as a skeleton bunny, fighting to regain your throne as prince of Hell while armed with drill (more like a ring blade) and a huge variety of improbably heavy weapons. I won't go into details because humour constitutes the game's greatest value but [b]Hell Yeah![/b] will keep you amused for a couple of hours, or for about 25 to 30% of its overall content. It's just the sort of product that makes me apprehensive of "comedy" games; past the initial chuckle you'll find that there's very little in the way of content.

Still, I'm giving [b]Hell Yeah![/b] a Thumbs Up because although I was apprehensive of its many questionable design decisions, I've found nothing too offensive during play and the shock humour DID succeed in making me laugh. Design decisions such as mapping jump to a face button, aiming to the right stick and firing the right trigger; it [i]seems[/i] cumbersome to do everything at once but there is enough leeway preventing you from getting frustrated. Or like holding jump for a floaty "jetpack"-like super jump. You dread the moment where you'll have to "float" just underneath a set of ceiling spikes but such a situation never occurs.

There's A LOT of material to go through so you're certain to get your money's worth, except that it does get repetitive after a while. [b]Hell Yeah![/b] makes an earnest attempt at providing as much monster variety as possible but inevitably, monster patterns and executions loop around and the game turns into a slog. You gain about a dozen different weapons but little to no difference in strategy. There's even extra value in the form of post-story extra missions; but they usually involve [i]platformer racing[/i] or killing a certain amount of enemies within a time limit. The most pedestrian of added content.

If you've already obtained this game during the Sega giveaway and haven't played it yet, then save it for a rainy afternoon or during a period when you're particularly down in the dumps. Avoid reading about it as much as possible and simply allow the story to surprise you for as long as it can. If you do not already have this game in your library and are currently staring down its 16,99$ price tag, then no, I most certainly do not recommend the purchase. Steam sale only, with the understanding that you're playing this game strictly for laughs.

22215767.review:
Hell Yeah! can be summed up as a tons of idea being jammed together, resulting in a bloody mess. It sorely lacks a design and quality control pass.

It really feels like the devs did a meeting, thought about all the things that might be cool to have in a game, put all of that in Hell Yeah, and then shipped it without actually checking that theses things would actually work.

Cool animated death scenes for bosses and mini-bosses ? Great ! Mandatory minigames/quick time events needed to trigger theses scenes ? Not cool.
Super colorful world with tons of details ? Awesome ! Busy background and color that mesh together making the action hard to figure out ? Bad.
A mode where you exploit your defeated enemies to gain treasures, like any respectable boss of Hell should ? Wow i never thought of that before, great stuff ! Having that mode be tied to real game time rather than ingame time when your game can be done in 2 play sessions ? Idea completely ruined.

I could go on an on about what works and what doesn't design wise, but i don't think that's really needed or interesting. Even basic guidelines like "don't put mandatory unskippable cutscenes after the checkpoints" are broken over and over again by this game, so going over every detail would just be a boring laundry list.

On the quality control aspect, the game somehow manages to have lag spikes even on powerful computers and the options menu is so bare bone that there is no way to change volume or cut music.

But, to be fair, when the game works, it can be pretty fun. And contrary to most games, it gets better as time goes on, thanks to all the cool weaponry you get. But there are just too many issues to really enjoy it.  On the whole it feels like either it was rushed to release, or there was a big failure on the design side.

Having finished this, I've got to say that I enjoyed my time on it. 

It's a simple, quite linear platformer. You pretty much always know where to go, and there's almost no reasons to go back, unless you want to do missions and get those secrets.

It does get a bit repetitive, it could have been a bit shorter, since near 70 bosses beaten I was getting kind of bored. 

There's nothing groundbreaking (except the saw!) or even remarkable about this game, but it doesn't stop it from having a great humor and a great artistic direction. It excel in the "cute-gore" category. I mean, it's good, but not "great".

Get it in a bundle or during a sale, and you'll get a good game that will last you a bit more than one evening!

21879688.review:
So the Rabbit prince of Hell has been caught in an embarrassing situation with a rubber duck and the only thing that can make it better is vengeance, that and getting the incriminating pictures back and showing everyone who’s boss.

This game is many things, crazy, colourful, insane, fun, psychotic, confusing and frustrating. So let’s start off with the story, it’s silly and fantastical to the nth degree, I loved it. It’s so off the wall zany that I had a blast with it and the crazy characters both friend and foe. The many worlds of hell are super varied and imaginative from the neon night club to psychedelic dream world I loved every one of them.

One particularly favourite part of mine was the huge amount of fatalities there were when taking down the 100 individually created enemies. They are all unique and die in a huge variety of bloody messy cartoonish ways. The vast arsenal of pure destructive weaponry was also another highlight, not feeling the magnum switch out for the flame thrower or one of a half dozen missile launchers, my favourite is the shotgun a must buy when you play.

Not everything is great though, the controls are very tricky to master and even when you get the hang of them they still mess you up from time to time. The DLC missions on a keyboard or almost impossible and took me a few frustrated hours to complete. The in game dialogue is also much more miss than hit with no laughs at all from me the whole play through. That being said this game is a lot of fun and I would recommend giving it a go for a few hours of entertainment. If this is on sale pick it up and try not to think too hard as you splatter demons on mass on your one bunny crusade through hell.
One final note, I know I said it before but play with a gamepad, the keyboard is not good and will lead to a lot of frustration with the precision platforming in some sections and virtual missions.

Have fun ːMMForFunː

21825215.review:
Disclosure: Got the game for free during a recent Steam promotion.

What a shame.
This is a great concept and visual style, wrapped up in poor gameplay design.

Controls are floaty, making timing puzzles for pushing objects (thankfully rare) and precision platforming (not so rare) a nightmare.
Conversations with boss monsters are unskippable, and will repeat themselves on death. If you happen to be above an instakill spike pit when one triggers, good luck not falling in when you regain control.
Enemies will continue to shoot you during the boss kill animations, meaning it's entirely possible to die while killing one of the monsters and have to repeat the battle.
Instagib traps (spikes, acid-spraying monsters) have a habit of sitting juuuuust outside the camera, meaning many occasions of leaping to your doom with no warning.
Heals are few and far between. Have a clutch situation against a hard-fought boss? Better backtrack through the whole level to heal up, or else you'll be stuck one hit from death every time the following checkpoints load.

It's unfortunate, because the game does have its charm (maybe an over-reliance on flat attempts at zany humour, but charming nonetheless). I wanted to like it, as some really nice work went into designing the 100 bosses (at least visually - gameplay-wise not so much). But in the end, I only got through it out of dogged determination. Just shy of six hours, completed the game with all achievemens, and no desire to return to it.

21729839.review:
This is a game where you HAVE TO:

- Watch the same "first encounter" animations over and over and over and over if you die and come back to the same creature again.

- Watch the same dialogues over and over and over and over if you die and come back to the same area again.

- Do the same things you just did over and over and over and over because the game uses a very spare checkpoint system.

- Watch the same "fatality" videos (which are very cool and funny at first) over and over and over for 101 times, until you get sick of them. 

- Watch the ending credits, which is VERY long, until the very end.

The game starts as a very colorful and different type of platform game, and for the first few hours it's very fun and even addicting. But after a while, the spare checkpoints start to infuriate you as you die countless times in some of the places. Make no mistake, this game is HARD. It starts to get boring and the game feels like a chore. If it wasn't for my OCD for unfinished games, I'd have stopped playing this at about 50th or 60th creature. After that limit, the game gets very bland very fast.

There are some neat ideas though. "The Island" is a very fun addition to the game. It helps keep things interesting and fun for a while. The creatures are really funny and most of dialogue is above average in terms of creativity (there are some old, boring jokes and memes though).

Overall, I'd recommend this game only if you have a lot of patience and an insatiable hunger for platform games. Otherwise, stay away from this game for the sake of your sanity.

21652359.review:
[b]Hell Yeah![/b] is a Metroidvania action platformer with a brilliant art-style and an outrageous presentation and story. You play the rabbit Ash, the Prince of Darkness. Your mission is to find 100 zany monsters in the depth of Hell to recover incriminating pictures of yourself. The story is completely bizarre and thematically fits the game well. 
The whole thing plays like a comic book come to life and the art is the main selling feature by far. Cartoonish violence and gore abound as you travel different parts of Hell, each weirder than the next. It works well.

Unfortunately Hell Yeah! suffers a number of suicidal gameplay choices that kill the fun, especially as you progress into the game. Tragically most of these are extremely easy to fix if the developers had the inclination to do so.[olist]
[*] Platforming in this game simply doesn't feel right. it feels incredibly 'floaty', as if the force of gravity changes throughout your jump. Imagine jumping against a low ceiling. Instead of your character immediately falling upon contacting the roof, it just hangs in the air and lands at the same time it would have if jumping in open air. This can lead to imprecision and frustrating deaths.[*] For a game that requires a lot of shooting, the inability to jump, shoot, and aim easily on a controller is utterly unforgivable. Here are the key binds: R trigger shoots, A jumps, and R-stick aims. Just try it right now, grab your controller and try jumping with A and aiming at something with the R stick. Your thumb effectively needs to use the R stick and push A at the same time. The easiest way around this is to simply allow the player to rebind jump to one of the shoulder buttons, but [i]the game does not allow any rebinds of controller keys.[/i] I had to play the game half with a controller for platforming sections, and half the game with a keyboard for combat. No reason this should be the case.[*] As mentioned, you have to kill 100 unique monsters throughout the game. While these are a highlight, they all must be finished off Mortal Kombat style. After depleting its health bar the old fashioned way, a Wario-ware style minigame pops up that you [i]must[/i] win. Fail, and the monster revives [i]and[/i] you take damage. While the finishers add to the overall game, the need for what is a complicated and even punishing QTE is not. There are some mini-games that are far harder than the monsters themselves (looking at you Hide and Seek).
[/olist]

I have other less important criticisms. New weapons aren't unique enough, difficulty progression isn't really there with regards to combat, and an entire side-game called Monster Island feels wholly unnecessary. But its the above 3 criticisms that truly hamper the game and it cannot be recommended as is.

21612909.review:
I don't even know how I got this game. I don't remember buying it. 
That said, this is BY FAR the best 2D platformer I have played in over 10 years.
If you are reading this review, that means you have at least seen the art style, and you are interested.
If you are interested, you will definitely not regret purchasing it.

This is just pure platforming fun. It is everything great about the classics, with modern visuals, and a bit of a more mature theme for those of us who grew up playing the classics. There is a very minimal tutorial that actually sort of pokes fun at people needing a tutorial, or maybe at games these days thinking people need a tutorial for everything. The levels are well designed, and there are some tricks to learn to overcome challenges. The bosses are fun, and bring a sense of nostalgia as well, having faced similar boss mechanics is so many classic platformers.

I don't know what some of these people are complaining about with this game. I see really nothing wrong with it at all. If I had to nit-pick some fault, I would have to say it can sometimes be annoying trying to stop on a dime, the character tends to want to walk an extra step or two when you stop. The best way I have found to couter that is to turn backwards and tap the reverse direction. You could also stop early and let him go, but I find that reversing works best for me. As for input, keyboard and mouse works best for certain situations that require you to aim and shoot while jumping across platforms, but the xbox controller works well enough too. I typically use the xbox controller and never really have a complaint. Only once I got a little frustrated with a boss fight, it was hard shooting while dodging his attacks, so I switched to keyboard and mouse, and beat him first try that way. You do not have to go through menus to change your control inputs. Just pick up the controller if you want to use it. I have no real complaints about either method for controls, both work great, but we all know the advantages of keyboard+mouse, that has nothing to do with the game.

I don't know what else to say. Stop wasting you time, and buy this game!

21545635.review:
Hell Yeah is a game about Ash, a skeletal Rabbit who is the ruler of Hell. He is blackmailed with photos of him cuddling with his guilty pleasure: ducks in a bath tub. These photos have been posted online, and already have 100 likes. So the obvious solution to this problem is clearly killing all 100 monsters in Hell who have liked these photos.

This description pretty much explains everything about the game play. The tone, the zaniness, and the mechanics are all in-line with the premise of this 2D side-scrolling romp. It is not a particularly difficult game, but it is reasonably entertaining from start to finish. You will experience varied levels, a wide and bright colour palette, and mini-games galore.

If you are looking for a new classic side-scrolling adventure that tests your skills, resources, and reflexes, you should certainly look elsewhere. However, if you just want to play something that is the equivalent of watching old Saturday morning cartoons, with a very violent twist, you may find something here.

6/10 "Okay"

21495466.review:
[h1]Story (No Spoiler)[/h1]

You play as Ash a rabbit who also happens to be the prince of hell, your journey will consist in swimming throughout a lot of funny references, crazy minigames and overkill moves.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

This game is a platformer, you have two diferent gameplay styles one using a death wheel where you can split your enemies in half while making them in swiss cheese, calmly dig into some kinds of terrain or dash your way through them. The other play style without the wheel allows double jump, climbing up perpendicular walls. In this playmode sometimes you don't have your guns so you have to use the ones provided by the stage. The variety of guns in this game is great you have a pistols, machinegun, minigun, rocketlauncher, flamethrower, holy water gun (yup, this is a thing) and much more.

[h1]Graphics and performance[/h1]

Great variety on stage design you sometimes can get lost but the map is really handy and will help you find the way. The performance is great, I never noticed any slowdown of stuttering in my playthrough.

[h1]Audio[/h1]

I was surprised by the soundtrack of this game, the songs match every level perfectly.

21490414.review:
You know how you've always wanted to play a demonic stygian rabbit prince with a buzz saw and missile launcher?  Now you can!  This is the strangest tale about a bunny in Hell since Matt Groening started drawing.  

Hell Yeah! is a platformer (shooting type), which feels like a slight throwback to Sonic The Hedgehog in areas (especially a casino level).  I say slight because the similarities are superficial.  As a platformer, it is not the best, and far from the worst.  The design is good enough to be a fun game. 

Where the game really shines, though, is the creativity of the design, but that is not without criticism.  You will quickly forget that you are in Hell, and there is no logic to the levels or encounters.  It's as though the designers put whatever was on the top of their heads and said "that's cool, do that".  It gives the design a random feel, overall.  I don't say that as a bad thing, but the Hell theme gets lost in the craziness of it all.  Awkward ideas like healing from blood showers become commonplace very quickly.  

The game has a major overreliance on unlocks and minigames.  Fighting a monster opens a Mortal-Kombat-esque finishing movie, which is done by playing a minigame before performing the fatality.  These are very simple games that are extremely easy, often parodies of other games like Guitar Hero, but they are not always clearly explained and have very short timers.  There are sections of the game which require specific costumes to pass, which can be confusing when there are between 100-200 masks to go through.  There are sections of the game where gameplay changes entirely, with different vehicles or losing your wheel, these are practically minigames in themselves.  None of which are fully realized enough to be a full game.  

The major sin of a bad platformer, of course, is poor controls.  Tight controls are what separates great games from bad ones.  This game has almost good controls, but the issues that it does have make the game frustrating, and are very apparent in the side-missions.  You continue to move after you stop moving sometimes, rolling off of ledges or into obstacles too easily.  The jetpack isn't always reliable, though when it works it is useful.  The worst problem is with getting hit.  Most classic platformers had the sense to give a player slight immunity after getting hit, not for easy playing but because the consequences for getting hit can be catastrophic.  This game sucks at that, and is a good example of why games like Mario were made like they were.  A single hit throws you back without control, where you can immediately get hit again and start bouncing around like a pinball with limited movement.  When this happens, you can still move, but the results can be unpredictable.  When one-hit-kill osbstacles are present, the game just becomes frustrating.  

There are a variety of weapons and cosmetic unlocks for the game, which are accessed as rewards, or through the in-game shop (not real money, fortunately).  The guns are interesting, but you can pick one you like and use it for most of the game, there is not much reason to switch weapons around.  The shop quickly becomes irrelevant when you get enough money, which is plentiful, and you buy out the store.  At that point, you still collect money, but why bother?

For all of its faults, though, it is a fun platformer and an easy game to get 100% achievements on.  Not awfully difficult, and not awful.  It certainly is worth it just for the craziness of it.

You're a fancy bunny.  Together we're happy.  You will be my honey.  We'll never be lonely.  Little rabbit, oh my little rabbit, deep inside you...deep inside you, you're not a nasty one.

Los controles, excelentes. Lo jugué con teclado y responde genial, así que imagino que con control ha de ser igual o mejor.

21428619.review:
Hell Yeah! is a game about the prince of hell, trying to discover who took a picture of him playing with a rubber ducky while taking a bath. The picture is then sent out and 100 monsters have seen it. Your goal is simple. Figure out who took your pictures, and make your minions pay. You do this by jumping around and slaughtering said minions of hell using both your giant wheel of death, and a wide range of weapons, like Bazookas, Miniguns, and Grenades.

Hell Yeah! is a game full of charm, and every main monster you slaughter is greeted with a fun mini-game that upon completion gives you an insanely well crafted animation of you destroying the monster, ranging from the Invaders shooting rainbows at it, to a satellite shooting a laser down from space to obliterate the creature. A lot of the charm also comes from the great writing, which also teases some of the cliches that come with a platformer, as well as the fact that the game never takes itself seriously.

The level designs all feel varied, and the game also introduces tons of little mechanics that give you a sense of variety beyond just jumping and running, such as jumping into a cannon to shoot yourself around the level. The minions you kill are also varied in style and attack. Some enemies will require you to just go up and attack, taking them out quickly and efficiently. Some may require you to solve a small puzzle or discover some element of the stage that can interact with them, possibly harming them in the process. Through it all, fighting these enemies never feels like a chore due to the large amount of killing animations, and varied ways the game requires these enemies to be taken out.

The game also features several bosses, while the bosses so far have hearkened back to a normal playing style, they don't feel boring or out of place. They're all varied in mechanics and provide more humor as the main character and the boss banter a little before combat is initiated.

Hell Yeah! is a well crafted metroidvania style action-adventure platformer filled to the brim with great humor, and comical gore that's perfect for anyone. The achievements are also easy and great for any Achievement Hunter (or player) who wants a break from a serious game to net a quick 100%

If I had anything negative to say about the game, it would be about its length. It only took me 8 hours to beat and collect all of the achievements. The length of the game is slightly alleviated by having hats and wheel skins for you to collect, as well as the Virtual Rabbits DLC which is supposed to provide a few more hours of entertainment; however, these don't completely shift the weight off the games length, but it does at least provide some replayability.

Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10.

I got it for free but I can't really complain about the price at all.

The game took me 10 hours to beat including all achievements. You can't go wrong with at least trying the game. Some of the scenes are comic and everytime you kill a monster you play a "minigame" in order to finally defeat the monster. Said monster is then added to your Island; it's another game-mode that monsters you've defeated basically "work for you" by finding money, gifts, HP, etc. There are about 101 monsters. All of them must be defeated to finish the game. There's plenty of missions to go along with your quest but do not need to be completed to finish the game.

Controls ARE sloppy, it was really frusturating when I kept wallkicking and falling unintentionally. The wheel that you're in does not have traction so you'll 'slip' whenever you stop moving. Some of the dialogues from monsters are repeated when you fail to defeat the monster so you'll have to go through the whole dialogue again after you die. 

I give it an 8/10. I only wish there was more replay value. After you finish the game, you might be getting that "thank god it's finally over, now I can finally uninstall this for good" feeling. Maybe.

21358192.review:
Hell Yeah! is an action-platformer where your goal is to slay the 100 monsters that saw your embarassing photos. Ash, the Prince of Hell, definitely wants to protect his image. The game packs plenty of jokes and copious amounts of blood. It's also built like a metroidvania, but at the same time, doesn't feel like one.

Also, there are a number of problems with this game that interfere heavily with the fun experience of slaying and collecting monsters. Let's start with those problems first before going into what the game does right.

[b]The Issues[/b]
[list]
[*]The game resolution seems to be 720p and is upscaled to any higher resolutions. This gives it a blurry look which is unpleasant. I was able to look past it because the gameplay kept me engaged until the other problems revealed their final form.
[*]There is a slight momentum to Ash's movement which causes the game to feel clumsy. This can result in unintended falls if landing on the edge of a platform or slipping since angled surfaces cause Ash to automatically slide down. 
[*]The wall jump in this game is Hold A and bounce off the walls type of deal. This kind of button assignment creates a frustrating number of incidents that result in bouncing backwards when you're just trying to platform normally with the double jump where if you hold A for each jump, you gain more height.
[*]There are some trial and error sections and blind jumps with the latter being rare. 
[*]When you die, any conversations or camera pan movements that highlight an area of the map are reset and play again. And again. With each and every death. This is one of the most annoying things about the game.
[*]The checkpoints are not the greatest.
[*]Monster slaying minigames can kill you if you're not quick enough to figure out the gimmick. Most of them are ok. Others are annoying.
[*]Very barebones options menu.
[*]I didn't like the sections where weapons are taken away as much, especially since you lose the rocket (wheel) jump and have to deal with the wall jump.
[*]Aiming can be difficult and when jumping around at the same time.
[*]You don't explore for hidden items. It's mostly a finding cash type of deal to spend in shops.
[/list]

Hell Yeah! has good points too. I liked the silly customization. The humor seemed fine to me. I liked the monster descriptions. Drilling through things felt pretty good. The visual style looks good. Some of the monster slaying mini-games are fun or over-the-top (some of them are repeated). It has a weird management meta-game. Finally, the action portion seemed just fine and the weapon variety is there to support it.

I can only recommend this game to people that have more patience than me for trial and error. Based on my experience, I have to give it a thumbs down, which is a shame since I enjoyed most of my time with the game, but lost any desire to continue. For reference, I slayed 60 out of 100 monsters.

Juego lleno de gore y humor, muertes de monstruos super épicas, y lo más original, para mí, los minijuegos para que la muerte salga bien xD

En cuanto a la jugabilidad.... bastante buena, la verdad, es fácil de acostumbrarse, y poco a poco aumenta el nivel de dificultad.
El sonido mola muchísimo, me encanta la b.s.o del juego, mezcla el rock en momentos de acción y en un nivel en particular, que es una cárcel, aparece una música tetrica que a mi, al menos, me dió mal rollo xD

No se que durabilidad tiene, pero se que a cualquiera que le guste el gore y el humor.... y el VICIO debe comprarlo.
Quizás 12,99 € aquí en España es mucho, si lo pilláis en rebajas bien, pero si os comprás tarjeta de steam y no sabéis muy bien por donde tirar.... yo lo invertiría en esto.

Nota final: 9,5 (más que nada por que recientemente con un boss me cabreé un poco por que no paraba de morir, pero esta ahí, rondando el 10)

21333069.review:
Hell Yeah! is SEGA doing what it does best which is delivering another tight platformer. The game is silly but not in a bad way at all. The protaganist is an unlikely "hero" set out to exact revenge on his enemies who have publicly embarrassed him due to his love for "Duckies". The levels are crisp and detailed. The controls are tight and easy and simple to learn. The objective is to detroy all the monsters in a single level to open up the last door to the boss before moving on to the next area. The game is not serious at all and it is obvious from the short introduction during a new game and it finds several ways to make you crack a smile along the way. The only downside is the length of the game which is purely based on your level of skill with platforming. Players who are familiar with the game will find themselves having a good laugh and breezing through under 10 hours or so and others may find it a bit harder to purchase every unlockable and find every secret.

It may not be the blockbuster title you're looking for but this is definitely a game you should grab if you see it on sale! The platforming is perfect and it shows SEGA has mastered this genre over the last couple of decades.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game [/quote]

The game is... meh. It's not terrible, nor is it unplayable. 

Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is a 2D game about a rabbit living in hell who is the prince of the Underworld. Somehow, someone managed to take photos of the prince in the bath playing with his duckies, you, play as the prince and you must find the culprits behind taking those embarrasing pictures and to remove your nickname of being a pussy

Hell Yeah! is a fun game, the graphics are really nice. The animations look like something from Pixar and Dreamworks Animation SKG cartoons, only much, much more gore. The music is okay, nothing special. The game heavy relies on jokes and silly crude humour and jokes around with game developers and making games. Although its fun at first, it can get quite boring after a while

The gameplay is fun but can get very repetitive. Each zone you have to find a limited amount of souls, after you can either go to another zone or battle a boss. That's what you do over and over again, and it get can get very boring very quickly

Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is fun, but can get boring and repetitive after a while...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]
[i] Provided it is in a sale, price drop, giveaway, gift or even given to you as a free game, otherwise... [/i]

[h1] NOT RECOMMENDED :( [/h1]

21319194.review:
(Disclaimer: Pese a criticarlo tan fuertemente, el juego realmente me ha gustado. Sólo intento valorarlo objetivamente)

Cosas que sí me han gustado:
- Los diálogos son verdadero oro, 10/10. La traducción también magnífica, de las pocas ocasiones que no me he arrepentido de jugar en español.
- El estilo artístico y los diseños (especialmente el de Ash) son buenísimos.
- El gancho inicial es alucinante, los primeros minutos te agarran y no te sueltan. Primera impresión brutal.

Cosas que no me han gustado:
- Se llega a hacer algo repetitivo y parece que pusieron tantos enemigos sólo para hacer que el juego durase más (las horas que un juego te dura no son indicativo de calidad!!!). Esta impresión la recibo especialmente cuando los minijuegos empiezan a repetirse continuamente, y los diseños de los enemigos van cada vez a peor.
- Al final terminas también con demasiadas armas de las cuales usarás 2 o 3, ya que la inmensa mayoría son mejoras de las que ya tenías, y hace que cambiar de arma sea un incordio, incluso usando los números del teclado.
- Las zonas parecen bastante inconexas y si no fuera por los indicadores de objetivo no sabría qué hacer. Los escenarios son laberínticos y en ocasiones si no usas el mapa es bastante fácil perderse, ya que hay muy pocos puntos de referencia.
- Las mecánicas del jugador (me refiero a serrar y disparar) no me dieron la impresión de que encajaran entre sí, y muchas veces de hecho parece que se olviden de que tienes la sierra porque casi todos los enemigos o son inmunes o es más fácil simplemente dispararles. Ocasionalmente aparece algún enemigo con el que sí que debes usar la sierra, pero son la excepción, y teniendo en cuenta que la sierra da bastante la impresión de ser el arma principal, no estoy seguro de que deba ser así.
- El argumento es bastante meh, no esperaba nada y aún así acabé decepcionado. El final ni siquiera me dio sensación de clausura.
- La isla al final no sirve para mucho.
- La música encaja pero no destaca demasiado.

Igualmente está guay, me arrepiento de no haberlo jugado antes!

21307843.review:
[h1][b]7 / 10[/b] - Hell Yeah![/h1] [i](Expect about 8 hours of play time out of this)[/i]

[b][u]Pros[/u]:[/b]
[list]
[*]You're the prince of hell, a rabbit.
[*]Very nice art style and animations.
[*]Fun, comedic writing everywhere you look.
[*]Some solid music tracks.
[*]Many weapon options. (10+)
[*]Metroidvania-like, but quite linear.
[*]Interesting death animations and minigames.
[*]A little character customization.
[*]Controller support.
[*]Rebindable keys and buttons.
[*]Achievements.
[*]Some bonus content such as hidden cosmetic items, zone completion percentage, side missions and a leaderboard.
[*]In-game shop with optional upgrades.
[*]You can make monsters work for you as slaves after you kill them. Sometimes they get angry or sad and you have to straighten up that attitude.
[*]Zone maps and monster radar.
[*]Load times are less than a second.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons[/u]:[/b]
[list]
[*]Hitboxes are always questionable.
[*]Movement is sometimes floaty and awkward.
[*]One of the abilities you get early on can screw up your platforming by activating unintentionally.
[*]There's QTEs or minigames that only give you enough time to figure out what to do, and no time to do it, so half the time you're doomed to fail(and you'll take damage or die from it).
[*]Some minigames ask a multiple-choice question that you could not possibly know the correct answer to, because it's just randomness in an attempt at being funny.
[*]Pure RNG achievement for winning the jackpot on a slot machine.
[*]Missing achievements for many things such as 100% completion, collecting all weapons and upgrades, completing all side missions, buying everything, finding every hidden item or various island tasks. So doing those things seems pointless. There's potential for challenge runs too where you restrict your health and weapons.
[*]A lot of the fights were very easy, including endgame.
[*]There was no ending. As soon as you land the final blow, it just immediately cuts to the credits.
[*]The death scenes are repetitive after a while and can't be skipped.
[*]It's easy, and I didn't even use some of the items from the shop that make it easier.
[*]The game seemed to drag on a bit. It felt like there were way more monsters than there needed to be when so many were killed in the same way as multiple other monsters in the zone that weren't challenging in the first place, only time consuming.
[*]Graphics options only consist of resolution and a fullscreen toggle. Capped to 60 FPS.
[*]Gifts from the island are extremely insignificant.
[/list]

21307289.review:
Hell yeah is a game that seems to be edgy and irreverant for the sake of being so. The jokes aren't clever, the platforming is weak, and the combat is boring. It's such a shame that such a good art style got attached to such a crap game.

Here's how the game plays out: awkwardly platform your way through some beautful level, with gorgeous animation, collecting coins, and find an enemy. Wear down his healthbar with your generic platformer gun of choice (such thrilling choices as, rockets, or machinegun, or flamethrower) When his HP hits zero, play an unassociated warioware microgame (Click on the shark not the missiles lol im so random guys) and watch a tragically poorly designed XTREEEEME deathblow play out, that you cannot interact with. (in this case fire hundreds of missiles until your enemy explodes into copy pasted giblets). Then the game incredibly slowly scrolls to the door that killing that enemy opened, (which can be multiple screens away) shows it opening, then slowly scrolls back. Repeat until you find a boss. Watch the boss throw projectiles at you while you wait for your gun ammo to regenrate. Kill the boss. Microgame. Thats it. 

There's a facebook like subgame of assigning enemies you kill to "Toil away in the HP mines", and a shop that you can spend currency on to upgrade your weapons in a linear "make shoot harder.. durrr" way. The entire game falls back on it's "extreeeeme and edgy" personality, even the damn "quest" dialog does it. (Which by the way, has such great quests as "Kill Kill Kill Kill": Kill an enemy to unlock a door)  

If this kind of irreverance sounds fun to you, go for it; Besides the great art, that's all this game is. Otherwise Pass.

Started replaying this after a long time thanks to the Make War Not Love 3 giveaway and had forgotten how epic it is. It's kind of a short twin-stick/light bullet hell platformer with occasional puzzle parts.

The humour is basically something a 14 year old Bart Simpson would think up, but it's just so thickly laid down that it makes the game hilarious.

It's pretty challenging but also gives you something to do if you're burned out of more serious games. It has some cute gimmicks like The Island and the customisation features. Amusing minigames/animations appear when you kill enemies. There's a lot of pretty funny text in the game too.

Easily one of my favourite modern platformers.

21303842.review:
(This game has been suggested by Vallinek and given courtesy of..... wait.... SEGA?!)

HELL YEAH to HELL YEAH!!!   KILL KILL KILL!!!!!  A great indie game developed by Arkedo and published by SEGA.   Wait....does this make this indie or third party? ..... Both?  Well, alright then.~

Play as Ash, a mixture between Jumpy the Rabbit King from the cartoon Hero 108 and Laharl from Disgaea, who acts as the new ruler of Hell after his father mysteriously passes away (no, you won't find out why and the plot doesn't go that deep).  Ash rules hell with an iron paw...until one day, someone snapped photos of him f*cking a rubber ducky in a bathtub and posted them on the Internet.  Ash sees this and is infuriated to find 100 views on the article.  To quell his vengeance, he must kill 100 denizens of Hell.   Did they see the pictures?  Are they innocent?  Who cares?!  100 souls will quell his anger.  One for each view of that article.

With your primary weapon as a giant buzz-saw blade equiped with guns, rockets, grenades, lasers, etc., you can't really go wrong with killing.   Every finishing move is a mandatory minigame that often leads to a brutal demise of your victims.  Ash really is one ruthless rabbit who doesn't give a f*ck.

PROS:
Tons of ways to slaughter
Great humor
Memes here and there (spot them all)
Easy to pick up and play
Achievements  (easy 100%)

CONS:
Not worth full price ($15)
Obligatory jackpot achievement
Too short
No achievements for doing more than 10 side-missions
Some obligatory minigames can either be too easy or too repetitive (if you liked WarioWare type games, then you may enjoy it)
Ending song loops 5-6 times after you beat the game...gets annoying
Only one save file
Very limited replayability (you beat the game, you can roam around, play slots or complete challenges...or DLC challenges, but that's about it. Aside from that, the only thing you can do is reset your file to get additional gameplay.)


I grew up with Nintendo.  I'm starting to like SEGA more nowadays.  This game isn't worth full-price, but it is worth playing if you find it on sale.  Thank you, SEGA, you done good.  ^_^

So, do I recommend this game?  Hmm....what was the name of this game again?   Oh yeah.....HELL YEAH!

8/10

21289755.review:
This game is what happens when a 14 year old finds his older brother's Invader Zim DVDs and begins his foray into becoming an edgelord. The writing is super cringey, with plenty of references to memes that were stale even when this game came out in 2012. The graphics are all super saturated and vibrant and you never know what to focus on, and the level layouts are that unsatisfying, Jazz Jackrabbit-esque platformer layout where you just kind of meander around a stage until it's over instead of progressing in a meaningful path. The controls are insanely floaty, like uncomfortably so, and the game's got no gamefeel to speak of. There's no impact from any of your attacks or jumps or anything, it just all feels weightless and weak. The music also just kind of drones on; it's white noise at worst, tiredvideogamemusic.mp3 at best.

That being said, some of the art assets are really nice looking. The HD sprites are appealing and some of the character designs are decent. The animation is alright too and I appreciate that they tried to make the game colorful even if they overdid it and it's hard to focus on anything. 

During my 20 minutes with this game I just thought "I could be doing literally anything else. Hm. I should go do that."

21275938.review:
Remember when platformers weren't all trying to be arty metaphors for life, loss and all that other fancy crap? If you find a metaphor in Hell Yeah's relentless assault on your eyes and sanity, it's only because it's about to get dropkicked by an angry demon rabbit riding a giant spinning death blade with a jetpack on the back.

This is one of those games where the design process didn't involve whiteboards and long discussions, but some chemist's secret stash being ground up and dripped into the artists' eyeballs. You're Ash, disgraced rabbit prince of Hell, on a quest to kill 100 wacky monsters who saw paparazzi photos of you playing with a rubber duckie in the bath. That's as sane as Hell Yeah! ever gets. It's a game where firing shark missiles is all in a day's work.

 Hell Yeah review Hell Yeah's drillable rocks look delicious. You'd eat that at the funfair.
Getting to your enemies is relatively standard platform fare, with the twist that you can often drill through obstacles, boost jump around the place, and acquire different weapons. Actually killing your foes, however, involves playing Warioware-style microgames such as stealing honey from a suspicious bee to unleash an appropriate fatality move, which might be having a dinosaur bite their head off for you.

It's the chaos of Earthworm Jim in the levels of Sonic the Hedgehog 2, with a little Ren and Stimpy/Invader Zim (delete according to age) thrown in for good measure. Gags and minigames repeat more than they should, but still survive the repetition of gags and minigames repeating more than they should, which both gags and minigames do.

The action itself, while enjoyable, soon lets things down. While Hell Yeah! is a fantastic looking game, it's one that paid more attention to looking good than playing great. There's so much going on most of the time that it's often hard to take in and get a proper read on the levels and what's going to hurt if you run straight into it.

More routinely irritating are the controls, where double-jumps, skids and simply being knocked back by enemies will often frustrate you. You want an Xbox 360 controller for this one. You could play it with a keyboard, but only in the same sense that technically you could fly if you flapped your arms hard enough. Either way, prepare for unhelpful checkpoints, and the irritations of repeated cutscenes and similar hold-ups soon being promoted to fully-fledged annoyances. They take the shine off the chaos rather than the fun out of it, however, and you soon return to the forward momentum Hell Yeah! needs.

The game's obvious enthusiasm carries it over these bumps in the road, and if you can forgive, you can easily forget in the race for the next bit of insanity. Hell Yeah! is no platforming classic, but it's cheap enough to be worth a punt if you like the idea of its craziness, and crazy enough to get your money's worth long before the end.

THE VERDICT
72/100

Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit
Gory, beautiful chaos, if a little frustratingly rough behind the scenes. A good afternoon’s chaos, and that’s what matters.

18052464.review:
I’m all for games trying to reach lofty goals and explore new styles and messages, but sometimes you just wanna kill shit. For times like this you can turn to Hell Yeah!, an unapologetic cartoon gorefest about finding and dismembering demons. There’s a story to it, but really you’re on the hunt for blood and money, the money there to let you buy more bloodletting implements. It’s about what I expected on the surface, but what I didn’t expect was a surprising amount of variety in how I would be executing my foes.

You are Ash, the bony, lupine heir to the throne of hell. Some dickhead demon decides to snap some pics of you in a compromising position, and you’re out for revenge. Not just revenge against the photographer, mind you, but against every demon in hell that knows what you look like naked. That comes to a nice, round 100 demons to murder, scattered across ten sprawling districts of hell. Some clever platforming and puzzles will get you within striking distance of your foes, and a quirky minigame will finish them off. The more demons you kill, the more of hell’s doors that will open to you and the more tools you’ll have to traverse levels, ultimately leading to the mastermind behind your embarrassment.

On the surface this is a platformer, one that flirts with being a metroidvania without ever really opening up enough to commit. Ash controls normally when on foot but for most of the game he’ll have some infernal sawblade-jetpack thing that makes his jumps extremely floaty and his touch deadly. Early foes can be dispatched just by grinding on them with your blade but later ones are armored or electrified, prompting the use of a wide range of upgradable firearms. The sawblade can also drill through different types of hellstone, with more added to the list as you progress. Levels are huge but mostly linear aside from alcoves stuffed with cash, though as you gain new powers like dashing you’ll open up access to new parts of previous levels. They start out as brimstone hellpits and prisons but progress to Sonic-esque factories, casinos, and more.

This doesn’t even touch on what I find engrossing about the game, despite being a solid foundation for a platformer. I mentioned minigames, and I wasn’t kidding; to finish off every one of the 100 demons on your hit list, you have to pass a WarioWare-style game. Examples including timing button taps to rev your sawblade, sniping a demon through a scope, playing red light, green light with a mechanical beehive, and picking a rabbit egg out of a dinosaur nest. The elaborate kills are related to the minigame as well, like the dinosaur nest one conjures a giant egg that hatches a T-rex that bites off the unlucky demon’s head. Every single one of these encounters is different and exciting, and some can even be a little tricky to grasp in the few seconds given.

What gives the game even more variety than that is the fact that every demon is a unique character that calls for a different approach to kill. Early on you can sawblade or shoot most of them but soon you’ll encounter ones with shields, ones you have to drop things on, ones that hide in underwater mazes, ones that man turrets that have to be turned back on them, and more. No matter how far in you get you’ll still be seeing new enemies with new gimmicks to defeat, and they all have their own models and animations and backstories. Even better, dead demons get sent to The Island, which is a side area where you can make them work to provide you bonuses. You ARE the king of hell, after all!

It’s all wrapped up in an absolutely lush, vibrant art style that borders on garish most of the time. Few platformers are this bold with colors and cartoony designs, but Hell Yeah! leans into it with its wonderfully animated characters. The soundtrack is more than up to the task and includes some fine selections for the shop and boss tunes. Really it’s a big, bright, messy, silly game about demons killing demons, and it revels in every aspect of it. There’s no deep plot to follow here but there are tons of secrets to find and a whole world of kooky characters and hilarious ways for them to die. And when you’re in the mood for some therapeutic slaughter, you really don’t need anything more than that.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

16859361.review:
[h1][b]My score: 6/10[/b][/h1]
Playthrough time: 8 hours (a total of 9 hours including the time to get the Jackpot achievement)

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+Lovely, totally over the top design - wacky and insane things all over the place
+Good looking graphics
+Works very well with a 360 controller
+Some nice changes of pace like the twin stick space shooter levels
+Good soundtrack

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-Somewhat sloppy controls
-A combination of sparse checkpoints and sadistic design makes you replay long sequences

[h1]Performance notes:[/h1]
The game is great for using the Xbox 360 controller and playing on the TV from the couch. The game feels like it was made for the 360 controller, so I never played with the keyboard.

The game has low system requirements, so it should run well on most computers. For me it always stuttered for about half a second each time while auto saving, but this was the only issue I encountered.

[h1]Main review:[/h1]
Hell Yeah starts off with a story just as wacky as the rest of the game. You play as Ash, the skeleton bunny prince of hell, who has gotten private pictures of him bathing with a rubber ducky leaked, so to not seem like a weakling, you have to kill the 100 hell monsters who have seen the pictures.

The game itself is mostly standard platforming. You jump around, avoid obstacles, shoot stuff and navigate the levels to get to the 100 monsters. Each time you encounter one, and get its health down by shooting it or using objects in the environment (depending on the monster) you will get to play a mini-game for a chance to land the killing blow. The mini games are often just matching the right button(s)/get the timing right, but there are a few other ones. There are a lot of different ones, so each one isn't used more than 3, maybe 4 times.

You get to upgrade your health and weapons, and some levels have vehicles: in one you control a submarine, and another one a space ship, and the game turns in to a twin stick shooter. This was quite a nice change of pace.

What the game does best is all the wacky things happening:
[i]
*Killing a monster by lifting weights, turning in to a super sized muscular bunny that kicks the monster into a soccer goal so the net slices it up? Check.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=473482545

*Starting in hell, but after a few levels placing you in an overly cute world, with background music with lyrics, where a woman with a French accent sings "You're a fancy bunny - Together, we're happy"? Check.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=473482634 

*Low on health, health bar reads "F**K"? Check.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474286510 

*Shop with rap music and a bunny robot clerk, bouncing lowriders in the background? Check.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474286379 

*Get the controls reversed and the game writes "LOL" at the screen, troll style? Check.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=473482603 
[/i]

I really enjoyed all these things, and I realised that for me, I didn't come back for the gameplay, I came back for all the wackyness. To come around a corner, hear the muffled rap music indicating a shop nearby, enter and hear the full "Money, money gold!" rap parody. The music in the game is very enjoyable and well done.

One design choice I didn't like is that after you stop moving, your character "glides" a bit, which makes it really hard to make certain jumps. You get the jump just right, but when you land at the very small platform, you glide over the edge. This makes the controls not feel very "tight". Combine this with the level design, which has the checkpoints maybe 3-5 minutes between, and some sadistically hard jumps with insta-death spikes if you miss your jump, and I guess that this will send quite a few gamepads airborne and lead to rage quits. When you repeat the same 3-minute section for the 10:th time and have to play it all over again, yet another time. You also have to rewatch any "cutscenes" that appear during that section.

I'm no pro platformer, so there were sections where I had to try many times to get it right, and even though I have lots of patience, I was close to quitting a few times.

So, I wouldn't recommend this game only for the gameplay. It's fine but it has its drawbacks. If you think you would appreciate all the crazy stuff happening, and can ignore the annoying parts, you're up for a good time with Hell Yeah!

14653832.review:
I've owned this since release, and just this moment got around to finishing it.

At it's core it's a fun little platformer with solid 2D graphics , but the deeper into the rabbit hole you go the more tedious it becomes.  

In the latter half of the game instakill spikes litter the walls, ground and ceiling.  Checkpoints and healthstations can be painfully far apart, and the only real reward you get for murdering bosses is opening gates to go do more of it.  The quick time events you must complete in order to kill a boss after you widdle their health down can range from simple to mind numbingly aggravating.  Sometimes you'll fight a boss till you're near death only for the quicktime event to be a demanding one you've never seen before, usually ending in you failing and having to start the battle over again from the last level checkpoint. 

For the most part the only reason to collect currency is to buy costumes, as most of the weapons are unlocked with story progression.

Had this actually come down in price over the 2 1/2 years since it's release I'd recommend it, but to this day apart from the odd sale it sits on the store glaring at customers for not wanting to shell out $15 for some hit and miss gameplay.  

At the end of the day the tedium of the latter half of the game prevents me from recommending it for anything other than a $5 sale.

You play as the Prince of Hell who has to kill 100 monsters that have seen the leaked compromising photos of the Prince playing with a rubber duck in a bathtub. The art-style is excellent, but so colorful that some levels are very hard to play through because there can be so much stuff on screen, in various colors, floating, flying, moving, jumping... you won't know where to turn or look.

One of the most fun games I've played in a while. It has its flaws, I'll get to that, but it has so many killer merits that it is just a pure pleasure to look at and especially to play. How a great game like this gets a 64 metacritic rating displayed and a truly awful game like house of dead ice skating ninjas gets a 79 displayed is dumb. Metacritic and the dimwit reviewers they combine are all ran by blindfolded monkeys banging on keyboards. This game is easily a 75 or higher. It can get absolutely frustrating at times but with a little effort you will get by. With practice, every ass is totally kick-able.

One of the most wildly creative games I have ever seen. It has great graphics with everything within a level pleasing to look at. The art direction is really creative. The real gem of this game is how you kill the main enemies. You go through the game and your goal is to eventually find and kill all 100 special monsters. Once you whittle its life bar down, it shows a screen where you do a brief mini-game to finish him off, ranging from tapping the A button (I'm using a wired xbox 360 controller, a controller is highly advised) to matching up a symbol or answering a question. After that, it shows a really hilarious kill animation. One had me do a little driving mini game where I avoiding things on the road for a little bit with a semi, then the kill on the special monster was a giant semi smashing into it then backing over it about 20 times. Another had a satellite shoot down a kill beam and a NASA control voice counted down from 5 and it destroyed the monster. There are a bunch of different ways and they are all cool to see. But of course there aren't 100 fatalities, one for each boss. There are much less than that so you will be seeing repeats of fatalities but, for me anyway, they mostly never get old.

House of Dead Ice Skater Ninjas is a pass. Pass it and play this. I am mentioning that game because at the time I had just beat that game right before I started playing this one. This game is a lot of crazy fun so you can forget garbage indie games like that. Loving every minute of this game. Besides this games (minor) flaws, I can overlook them because of how wildly fun it is and how creative the whole thing is.

Good work done here, 8/10

The best thing about the game: Visuals and soundtrack. Both meet very high standards in most areas.

Everything else is proved to be an underwhelming experience.

 You go about killing some "mini bosses" to unlock doors for bosses. If the idea of mini bosses excites you don't get your hopes up too fast. They have one attack pattern, are easily killed, although sometimes you must kill them without weaponry. 

When you get them to low hp, a mini game starts. The mini games have a lot of variety which ranges from tapping one key, catching falling stars, to tapping several keys at the same time, all placed in an awkward position (e.g. x+v+spacebar+e). The mini game you are given decides what will be the killing animation, which are all silly. What they do have in common is that they get boring quickly and can't be skipped. Some minigames have a timer so if you are not quick enough to read the instructions you will lose the minigame and actually take damage, potentially killing you which is highly annoying.

The platforming itself is mundane at best and worst, although you do get to fly with a spaceship, pilot an aircraft and drive a submarine. But even those things didn't offer a big enough relief from the overall boredom I was feeling. The most annoying thing in the game happens when you get hit: Similarly to oldies like Ninja Gaiden, you get knockbacked when you get hit. The damage immunity after the hit doesn't last long enough, so it is possible that the enemies play ping pong with you, you get knocked back into instant death spikes, or lose half of your hp because you got knockbacked into a wide boss and can't escape without getting hit a few more times.

If the beautiful background and fitting music is enough for you, by all means, this game has one of the the best I've seen. If you, however, care about gameplay more, you can safely skip this one.

10493135.review: I'll be honest....I didn't expect much from this game at first.  I got it in a bundle of software in which I was only interested in a couple of titles, but thought, "What the hell?  Looks corny.  I'll try it out.  I'm in the mood for something different."  This game surprised me with its take on the platformer genre - almost as if it's making fun of other platformers.  It was refreshing after playing through an FPS like Far Cry.  Elements and influences from other platformers like Metroid and Castlevania are clearly evident, but there's some Mario and Rayman influence in there too.  The game looks like it might be something made for kids, yet is decidedly adult oriented in its use of language and blood/gore, so one has to keep this in mind if in doubt whether on not they should get it for their kids.  Also, it sways drunkenly in difficulty between super easy and fantastically frustrating.  Instructions are sometimes in lack of abundance for accomplishing a mission, but for the most part they're thorough enough.  Certain parts are easier to play with a controller (like a lot of platformers) rather than keyboard and mouse, but others are much easier the other way around, so I found myself switching back and forth on occasion, which is a new experience for me on a platformer.  I completely recommend it, however.  I've had a lot of fun with it, and the dark humor in it made me laugh.  The story is ridiculous, nonsensical, and frankly HILARIOUS - again, a refreshing break from other games that I play.  As for price, I dont know that I would pay $15, but I got it cheap through Humble Bundle and it was worth every penny that went to it there.  If you happen to find it on sale, it's worth a buy, and I hope you find it as refreshing and funny as I have.  Enjoy!

10471790.review:
I have rarely played a game so criminally *boring*.  This game wasn't worth the pittance I paid for it.  It's not awful, it's not good, it's not even neutral.  It's aggressively uninteresting.  You play it and think you're getting something worth your time, with flashy colors and crazy stylings, but what you really get is a series of rote, repetitive minigames separated by frustratingly simple platforming marred by sub-par controls.

It's like an expensive car that turns out to be no better than a mid-range Honda.  Flashy trappings that make you feel empty when you go for a ride.

10423196.review:
This is a platformer with a sense of humour, it pokes fun at the publisher (sega) on many occasions. As a platformer it's pretty confident the controls are responsive, sometime to the point of being... Twitchy. Some of the areas or platform puzzles are near rage inducing in either difficulty or just because they don't explain what your doing.
If your a person who dislikes QTE's (quick time events) then I definitely don't recommend this to you. There are 102 boss monsters to kill and the final blow for all of them is a QTE or occasionally a minigame. Failure to perform it causes damage which of course will lead to death on quite a few of them.
There are weapons to unlock and upgrade, plenty of customisation options, some of which are actually requred to progress, thankfully when an item like that is used the nearest shop will stock it for free.

There really isn't much more I can say on the subject of the game really. The story is stupid, but it reveals in that. The combat is pretty solid and the final kills on the bosses generally are entertaining.
If I'm honest I'm not sure I would recommend this at its standard retail value, if it were sale then go for it.

Es un juego entretenido, con una buena banda sonora y unos gráficos coloridos dignos de SEGA. Sin embargo, el juego resulta algo insulso al intentar mezclar demasiados elementos de gameplay sin desarrollar demasiado ninguno. 

Y según se acerca el final del juego, se reducen el número de checkpoints y el control se demuestra ineficiente para lo que los niveles exigen del jugador. La cámara también tiene demasiado zoom, hasta el punto que es bastante probable morir por unos pinchos que estaban fuera de la pantalla. Además, los enemigos pueden dispararte de lejos, pero tius balas nunca viajan más allá de la pantalla, lo que me pareció bastante injusto.

No es un mal juego, aunque le falta centrarse un poco, pero le falta refinar los controles bastante. Y eso en un plataformas 2D es extremádamente importante.

9932430.review:
More of a test in psychological mettle than a fun pastime, Hell Yeah! is just one of those games that I vastly dislike, but just need to finish; Not for a sense of accomplishment, but just so I can say that I have the will power and pain threshold to survive this train wreck. The groan-worthy self-referential humor, poor 360 controls (playing with the keyboard and mouse is inherently better, so why even make using a controller an option?), nearly infuriating bosses/mini-games, a camera that is panned much too close (if the enemies are off screen, they can't be shot), constant need for backtracking, and incredibly horrific platforming are just a few chapters in Hell Yeah!'s grimoire of wretched gaming.

The worst part about it all is that I enjoy the basic concept. It's completely lost on this unfocused ludicrousness. If the art direction were more palatable and refined a bit (right now I'd describe the level appearances as borderline 5 year old, sugar rush, fever nightmare. Especially the "Cute" and "Club" levels), some of the mini-games a bit more clear and not detrimental to your health bar upon failure, and just one writer at Sega or Arkedo had a likable sense of humor, this game would be a sleeper hit.

 It would have been a gem if they could have blended Metroid-vania level design with fun Warioware style mini-games to break the flow. 

But no. This game bombards your brain with idiotic dialogue, collectibles that are a chore to collect, and brings you so very close to liking it before it curb stomps your hopes and enthusiams for it to be at least a mediocre game. It's almost a crime to put out something that could have just used 2 or 3 more months of development and clean ups. 

Maybe if Sega/Arkedo gave a rabbit's ass about it, they'd patch it occasionally. But will they? Hell No!

I had this game for a long time and never bothered to install it. Today, I installed this game to try it out, because the DLCs were on sale... Well yeah, finished the game in 1 sitting of 5-6 hours with 100% achievements. I have to say it was addictive, even though if it was pretty short. Also, the game was very easy, I did not get stuck for more than 5 minutes on something.

The graphics are just plain nice, the game has an intense amount of gore and the soundtrack is awesome. There's alot of old video games reference in this game, the characters are well done and they have interesting personalities, the game has alot of bosses ( Around 100 or 105, ) the level design is good and it's an amazing platformer. The game had some humor too.

Don't get me wrong, it has it's bad points too:

-Double jumping sometimes makes you wall jump, which can kill you.
-Sometimes you can reach places you shouldn't have reached that early, so you either need to die or have a hard time backtracking through that part.
-Somewhat short.
-The same ''Fatalities'' are re-used at least 4 to 6 times each, there's still about 20 though.

Overall, yes, I definately recommend this game. Just don't be scared of limbs, blood and the like!

9595715.review:
The game has decent ideas about killing, but that's it. The cutscenes for killing monsters are cartoonish and enjoyable at first, but gets repetetive after a while.

Colourful candy graphics.

Nothing in it has sense, though there are some lame atttempts. Like, when you kill monsters, they appear in your monsterpedia to bring some joy in the game by giving you scraps of information. You control a rabbit full of killing desire, but nothing else. Lousy attempts at comedy are the only ways he can surface anything in the game about himself, and that's it.

There is nothing to complete here whatsoever. Everthing you can get is straightforward along the path, and sidetracking is next to impossible. The weapons in game are uninteresting and you get them in bundles, instead of making it more fresh and funny to gain them (like for instance, take them from a corpse, or a secret compund, or some plot giving event, form the weapon from soemthing). The characters used in game to help rabbit, are episodic and at the end of it dissapear completaly (Nestor, the giant eyeball thing is more of a decoration). Shops are put in rare areas, the last area doesn't even have a shop I'm afraid, making player to relocate himself for whatever reason before the final battle.

The game mechanics are the ones that get the biggest blow. Using the pad its pretty much impossible jump and shoot anything due to lack of thumbs on your hands and index fingers. Enemies can shoot you from a great distance without problem, whereas when you try to shoot them, even when they're just pixels away from you main view, is impossible. The save system is just damm annoying. Its kind of hard to go anywhere in the game, once someone decides you can respawn with almost 0 HP, granting you eternal pain in the ass of finding any way to replenish your HP, which are scarce (either buy in shop, or find fountain or island).

And speaking of Island, I know its an in-game mini feature that shouldn't bother needlessly... but why does it have meat factory? Its purpose is to give our chap 30HP a bite, replenishing it.  What's the point of giving your character 30HP when you have mx 550HP and enemies hit you for 120 HP a hit? Its like toying with player.

The ending of the game is terrible. Let me just say: the mid fighting long non-skippable dialog is annoying, and the fact that after the final fight there is no after story for ash (did he got back his pictures at least? What about future himself?) leaves player craving for bloodlust. Judging by the game's title "Hell Yeah". you'd think people care about grand entrances in game.

All in all everything seems like a bad case of Castlevania clone.

Pro's:

+  candy graphic
+- many weapons... repetitive design and bundle gift
+- killing minigames!... which after a while get boring and you wish they were not there

- non-skippable cutscenes
- quirky controls
- save games that wants you to spend eternity dying looking for save spot
- childish brutality mixed with childish humour = bad taste
- most anticlimatic video game end ever,

9593565.review:
This is a quirky little almost-Metroidvania-like platformer that doesn't require too much skill to get through. You spend most of the game riding around in a spinning blade wheel (that doubles as a jetpack for limited flight) and fire various weapons to take down 100 bosses and all the little minions that get in your way. But there are segments where you pilot other ships with their own special weapons and even run around on foot without any weapons. The real selling point is the WarioWare style "microgames" you play once you've depleted a boss's health. They're all pretty easy and the end result is usually the same, but they're a fun little reward for your work.

With so much variation in the gameplay, it's a shock and a shame that it all ends up feeling so repetitive. Despite the large amount of boss microgames, a lot of them play similarly (stop something that is moving in a specific spot, press/mash specific keys/buttons, etc.). Add on the fact that there's far less than 100 of them and you'll start to get tired of them near the end. The special vehicles are a little bit of a letdown too with a couple of them playing exactly the same. Finally, outside of a few special cases, most of the weapons act essentially the same. To make matters worse, the shotgun is so overpowered and can blast through walls you normally have to drill... it's hard to justify using anything else once you buy it.

That being said, I'd still recommend this game. Overall, it's pretty fun, not too long, and has a silly sense of humor.

7/10

9225900.review:
Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is I guess an action platformer with puzzle elements. 

Its an enjoyable experience clocking in at around 4-6 hours depending on whether you go for 100% of the achievements. Its a very easy game to perfect, so if you're looking to improve your completion rate and its in your library play it. 

The graphics are cartoonish. yet work well with the game and atmosphere. Hell Yeah! is split up into different worlds, all as colourful and imaginitive as the next. Your objective is to kill the monsters(mini bosses) in place, there are also main bosses and a final boss. Your main way of getting around is a spinning wheel with spikes on it. You also have an assortmenet of weapons like machine guns, RPGs, shotgun, etc. You can customise your characters look and wheel, these customisations are just cosmetic but they're humourous. 

The story of the game is also quite entertaining where Ash(protagonist) has pictures taken of him in the bath and called out as being a pussy so he goes on a search for said pictures. The soundtrack on the game works well with the game and further immerses you into the game, where each world has its own track in place. 

There are some negatives and they're that the game even at 5-6 hours does slightly drag some of the monsters you have to kill maybe could of been removed. When you kill main monsters(mini bosses) you have a little mini game with a death animation. There are only a certain amount of death animations and mini games and where the mini games don't get annoying the kill scenes do and they break immersion from the game itself. 

Overall though the game is enjoyable its worth a look for a couple of pounds/euros/dollars but there are better action/platformers on the market.

8997359.review:
Well, this game started off feeling very low-budget and not in the good way, but that was the high point of my experience with it. The platforming is mediocre at best. Half of the time, it can be difficult to see what exactly is dangerous and what isn't, something that's immediately obvious from the first level where you, the so-called Prince of Hell, walk through flames without harm, except for those ones, which look virtually identical, especially in Hell which is composed of fire. Those flames will damage you, except for the ones that don't, got that? The story seems to start halfway through, like I missed a few levels or something, but no, it's just bad writing, the one consistent thing throughout the entire game. The jokes barely raised more than a weak smile at their best, which is rare. Landing a jump can be about as pixel perfect at times as Super Meat Boy, which would be okay a) you didn't slide everywhere like the ground was made of ice and b) if the levels weren't cluttered with useless junk as, unlike SMB's clean visuals, the cartoonish graphics throw everything but the kitchen sink into the background, foreground, every ledge, every trap.

Speaking of SMB, let's talk about respawning. How fast could you respawn in SMB? Instantly. Do you know why? Because a game in which you die that amount would get infinitely frustrating if you had to wait even a second to keep playing. Now, Hell Yeah is a game in which you can be stunlocked and die in just a few seconds as punishment for missing one of those pixel perfect landings or making a small error with it's clunky feeling controls. How long does it take to respawn? Well, the boss that made me just quit the game killed me in a method that took about five seconds before I actually died (I can't move or do anything during this period of time), another second or two for the death screen, another three seconds to respawn and then made me [i]rewatch the boss's unskippable introduction cutscene[/i]. This happens [b]every time[/b]. And because of the previous platforming issues, I have died quite a number of times on this boss.

A previous boss required me to kill it with its own trap. Except how you do that is such a screwup of game design, I actually went into the next area searching for a way to kill it, killed an entirely different boss which was so painfully simple (make it run into a wall) and then had to go back to kill the first one. The way back was guarded by spotlights which signalled another unavoidable, stupidly long death. They were easy to avoid on the way down, but the way back up was hampered by the awful controls and the fact that these spotlights haven't even got any form of pattern to them. One of them literally stopped and zigzagged across the tiny platform I needed to get to for over half a minute. When it got off, I immediately jumped up, only to find the spotlight suddenly rush back to see me and I die. Again. And respawn at the bottom. Again. When I finally got back to the boss, I found how you were meant to kill it and immediately found another checkpoint (the one thing this game mostly gets right) so I didn't have to climb up the tower of doom again. I jump up to the trap to set it off and have it track me to target the boss. I mess up, die, that's fine, my bad. I start again, jump up... and immediately die to the trap because, for no reason whatsoever, it's set up in a different way this time. It pointed in a random direction every time I respawned, half of which were instant death because of the stunlock meaning I get thrown immediately into another source of heavy damage.

The writing is boring, with no reason for anything other than your Facebook pictures got leaked or something, I feel like all of my motive was in a prequel game to this (if there is one, I'm not actually aware of it). The jokes lack any punchline half the time beyond "lol, the skeleton rabbit is naked, isn't this amusing? Why aren't you laughing? Maybe I'll tell it again three more times, that should get a laugh!" Everything wants to kill you for some reason, except the times they don't but you want to kill them for some reason. When (if) you do kill a boss, you get "rewarded" with a minigame, which are either stupidly simple, annoyingly finnicky, QTEs or simple "mash this button until you get RSI!". At first I was okay with it as it looked like each boss got its own unique game, but when they started repeating, my interest dropped further.

Do not buy this game. It's not worth £9.99 ($14.99), it's not even worth picking up on a sale. Wait until it's in a bundle with some more interesting games.
