This game is not as much terrible as it is mediocre. It was amusing at first, rolling around and shooting at anything that moved. And the fatality-like kills that resulted from defeating each boss were amusing at first ...

... and then repetition set in, more or less at the 30 minute mark. There's not much variety to the platforming. The colors are obnoxious. There's not a lot of variety to how to beat the bosses. And the fatalities are recycled later.

Again, it's not bad. It's just boring. The map is helpful to understand where you are and where enemies are. The gamepad layout is fairly intuitive. The controls are reasonably responsive. Technically, it's okay. But it's painful to play after a while because it's so dull.

Also, don't bother spending time with the Island, which is simple prison labor management system using the enemies you've defeated to generate more money. I barely touched this and still had plenty of money to buy EVERYTHING in the game.

Really, I only finished the game so that I can delete it without regrets and never think to play it again.

I also had one of the DLCs, Virtual Rabbit Missions, installed. Don't bother with it. They're lame timed missions, like race to the end within the time limit or kill all enemies within the time limit. I think each mission is about 30 seconds, so it's really not worth the money.

I'd probably give it a 3/10. Seriously, this game was so dull that I had to play it in small doses because it gave me headaches from the sheer boredom.

4955556.review:
A game that incorporates a strange mix of gameplay elements that have divided professional gaming reviewers. According to Metacritic, the game's average score is a 69; while it's range has varied from a 4 to an 8 out of 10. More on the later:

In the game, you're tasked with killing over 100 unique enemies, think of them as 'mini-bosses'. They're scattered throughout the world, in order to proceed in a map you have to kill a set amount. Along the way you gain weapon upgrades and progress through a loose story that might as well not be there. The maps are big, and while they have branching paths, you're always gently led to where you have to go next. So it's kind of like Metroid, but MUCH easier. You're NOT gonna get lost.

The stuff that contributed to its bad score: 1.the controls. They work, but don't expect to platform, aim, and shoot simultaneously and have an easy time at it. 2.The mini-games. Each time you get a unique enemie's health to 0, you're presented with a mini-game you must complete to finish them off (think 'Warioware'). Each game brings a unique death animation. It's cool, until you realize there are 100 enemies, around 20 games, and each death is 10-17 seconds long. It can get repetetive; but I found the games to be varied enough so that it never got tiresome. 

Overall, I'd say its a game that OBVIOUSLY had a lot of love put into it and it oozes a unique style. While it's a little on the easy side, there are very few side missions, and the mini-game novelty (and death animations) wear off a fifth of the way through, its still worth a purchase if you want a decent platformer; 7/10.

4385789.review:
Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit is a modern day take, and parody, of classid 2D platform games.  I found it very entertaining, with fun gameplay, impressive visuals (seriously, the aesthetic of this game is incredible, it looks really good), and lots of beautiful, gorey, gratuitous violence. 

Hell Yeah! sports great controller support, a nice soundtrack, and really reminded me of Jazz Jackrabbit in a way - it's the closest game I've ever played to it, and it really took me back.  If you've ever played Jazz Jackrabbit (if you haven't go play it now) you'll immediately see the resemblence, and you'll be reminded of a game Epic would have made had they had the resources modern day game creators do.  It has snappy load times, great optimization, a *huge* amount of customizable hats and skins for your character to unlock and find, and lots of weapons at your disposal to destroy your enemies with.

That said, it isn't a perfect game - the controls aren't very tight, they're actually pretty "floaty" (in a bad way), and dying can make you feel at times that it wasn't your fault, but rather the controller or keyboard.  It's not like Super Meat Boy where you know it was you and not the interface.  This, coupled with the fact that the respawn locations can get pretty far away from each other towards the later part of the game, can cause for some aggravating gameplay mechanics, where you're backtracking through stuff you've done 10 times before and keep dying at the same spot because you couldn't stop on a dime like you wanted to.  The game also doesn't have many options (graphical or otherwise) to set, it's really plug and play, and you can tell it was designed for consoles as well as the PC.  I couldn't even remap my buttons properly.

Besides those negatives, Hell Yeah! is a riot.  There are fun little minigames every time you kill a "boss" monster, but they do repeat themselves (there's 99 monsters, so this isn't too bad, as there is a large variety of the mini-games and they're all grapically pleasing and end with a huge explosion of blood).  There's also a section of the game called "The Island", and it's where all the "boss" monsters you've killed go to hang out - it's a neat little feature as you can micromanage them to earn you extra money, life, and special rewards like new hats and skins for your character.  I did find it a little weird you had to actually quit out of the game and go back to the main menu to access this area, but, as stated before, the game is optimized well so it wasn't a huge issue.

In conclusion, Hell Yeah! is a funny, fresh, current, and hip platformer that has a great aesthetic style.  I enjoyed it, although found it tedious at times.  Had it had better controls and a few more tweaks here and there this would be a must-play, but unfortunately as it stands it sits at the middle of the pack.  B

• Isn't cheap on color or detail.
• Minor technical issues, such as random crashes.
• Specific brand of humor, enjoyable if caught on. Constantly breaks the "fourth wall" and parodies many gaming tropes.

• Collaboration of "classic" style of exploration, reminiscent of Metroid & Castlevania, mixed in with elements of Mr. Driller & Dig Dug, feat. carrot missile-flavored Contra.
• Ludicrous minigames. In a good way.
• Floaty, yet sometimes excessively precise platforming with puzzle elements and clever moments.
• Make your wacky enemies work for you.
• Pandas shooting eye lasers.
• More than likely worth the time and price regardless of whether you enjoy the genres it represents.

Hell Yeah! is INCREDIBLY fun while it lasts as one can complete the game in about 7 hours. The game mixes elements from "Metroidvania"-games, 2D Platformers, shoot'em ups and WarioWare like minigames.
The different levels and characters offer a lot of variety and are presented in a brilliant art style. Many references to game classics and some bonkers scenes will make you laugh.

811486.review:
Hell Yeah isn't great, but it isn't terrible either. It's a mix of both. Let me explain:
The humor is hit and miss - at times it's genuinely funny, at times it's extremely childish. You could say it's for both kids and adults, but in my opinion that's nonsense and it just isn't consistent.
Platforming and killing is the heart and soul of this game. It performs well in the killing aspect, especially the finishing (mini-game) moves, and not too bad in the platforming aspect, but the controls take some time getting used to and the platforming is at times very imprecise, which results in you falling off ledges regularly.
And I really disliked the backtracking, even if it's for short distances. This is no Metroidvania game. Backtracking in this game is an artificial way to extend the game and it's highly unneccesary if you ask me. It is already packed with content so there's plenty of other stuff to do.
Seriously, if I had the chance to buy this game again I would've waited for a discount.

[Rating: 62/100]

954384.review: One of the best Metroidvania style games I've played. The visuals and audio are top quality, the gameplay is fun as well. This is a sure buy on a steam deal, but try the demo if you want to be on the safe side.

313771.review:
Hell Yeah is a game that is pure style over substance. Its most redeeming aspect is the sheer quality and quantity packed into its art style.  

The game itself is spent hunting down and destroying 100 "unique" monsters scattered across several large labyrinthine maps, evoking an almost Metroid II feeling.  The nature of this large fetch quest becomes tiresome after a while, and the liberal sprinkling of mediocre power ups do little to keep one engaged.  

Technically, the controls are a little spotty and downright uncomfortable with aiming of projectile weapons being handled with the right analog stick, and the playfield never feels properly presented, with enemies almost always being offscreen and too much of the screen's real estate being taken up by gobs and gobs of art.  

It's stylish and wacky, but everything underneath its unique coat of paint just isn't enough to carry this game.

1395059.review: Do you like the humor of Ren and Stimpy? Do you long for a comedic platformer like Earthworm Jim? Buy this game. Humorous boss fights, collectibles, and tons of minigames make this game a fun ride,

3822913.review: Hell Yeah! is a bat-shit crazy platformer with a great sense of humor. Prepare for an outrageous excursion into a rainbow explosion version of hell with a cast of wacky characters set to a rocking soundtrack. The gameplay is challenging and varied, allowing you to explore previously unreachable areas as you progress and unlock upgrades. You can customize Ash, the dead rabbit with a variety of different hats, weapons, and wheels of death ranging from saw blades and battle axes to sprinkled donuts and rubber duckies. Enjoyable boss encounters with unique mechanics and "WarioWare" like mini games used to murder the collectible mini bosses will keep you on your toes. If you're in an entrepreneurial mood, you can put your collected minions to work in a special zone called "The Island". What is there not to like? Seriously. Get this!
